{{flagicon|GBR}} Mike Broad |team1 = {{flagicon|GBR}} [[The Rank Organisation]]-[[Daimler-Benz|Daimler-Benz AG]] |teamsstart = 69 |teamsfinish = 47 }} The '''1977 London-Sydney Marathon''', officially '''Singapore Airlines London-Sydney Rally''' was the second running of the [[London-Sydney Marathon]]. The rally took place between the 14th of August and the 27th of September 1977. The event covered 19,000 miles (30,000km) through [[Europe]], [[Asia]] and [[Australia]]. It was won by [[Andrew Cowan]], Colin Malkin and Mike Broad, driving a [[Mercedes-Benz W123|Mercedes-Benz 280E]]. ==Background== The success of the [[1968 London-Sydney Marathon]] would inspired Australian advertising publicist Wylton Dickson, who had no previous links to rallying to organised the [[World Cup Rally]], which took place in [[1970 London to Mexico World Cup Rally|1970]] and again in [[1974 London–Sahara–Munich World Cup Rally|1974]]. But following the controversy over the running of the 1974 event, the [[World Cup Rally]] was cancelled and Dickson decided to organise another London to Sydney Marathon in 1977, with sponsorship from [[Singapore Airlines]], who were celebrating their 30th Anniversary, by running the longest car rally in history. The route would see competitors cross Europe and Asia in the first twelve days of the event before the cars would be shipped from [[India]] to [[Malaysia]] with competitors driving through the country and into [[Singapore]] for the next eleven days before being shipped to Australia for the last seven days of the rally. ==Results== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left; font-size: 95%;" |- ! {{Tooltip|Pos|Position}} ! {{Tooltip|No|Car number}} ! {{Merge|Crisis in Venezuela|date=August 2018}}
The Venezuelan economic crisis also known as Great Depression in Venezuela<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elestimulo.com/elinteres/la-gran-depresion-economica-de-venezuela/|title=La crisis venezolana ya tiene nombre: Gran depresión económica|date=23 October 2016|publisher=}}</ref>, refers to the deterioration that began to be noticed in the main macroeconomic indicators from the year 2012, and whose consequences have extended in time to the present, not only economically but also politically and socially.
== Origins == {{transcluded section|source=Crisis in Venezuela (2012–present)}} {{Trim|{{#section-h:Economy of Venezuela|2013–present}}}}
== Prices == {{Unreferenced section|date=November 2018}} Due to the lack of its own resources, Venezuela has traditionally exported all its oil abroad, so the [[Price of oil|energy crisis of 2014]] produced a strong inflationary trend. In June 2013, accumulated inflation in the last twelve months was 56.2%. The sharp drop between 2014 and 2016 in the price of oil, sparked fears of a risk of hyperinflation. In 2015, Venezuela reached the highest inflation rate in the last 35 years, and in March 2016 there was hyperinflation for the first time in recorded history. In October 2016, the economy continued to contract while inflation increased again. Between 2017 and 2018, prices rose 2616% - this increase combined with austerity measures and high unemployment negatively impacted the living standards of Venezuelans. At the same time the average wages decreased (real) and the purchasing power was significantly reduced.
== Employment crisis ==
After having completed substantial improvements over the second half of the 1990s and during the 2000s, which put a few regions on the brink of full employment, Venezuela suffered a severe setback in 2015, when it saw its unemployment rate surging to 1994 levels.
Venezuelan's unemployment rate hit 17.4% at the end of June 2017, with the jobless total now having doubled over the past 12 months, when two million people lost their jobs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archivo.entornointeligente.com/articulo/10183731/Central-obrera-cifra-en-185-la-tasa-de-desempleo-en-Venezuela-26062017/|title=Central obrera cifra en 18,5% la tasa de desempleo en Venezuela |work=EntornoInteligente|date=26 June 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
== Public debt ==
Public debt, which in 2010 represented 34.62% of GDP, doubled in three years, standing at 52.1% in 2013, reaching 52.98% of Gross Domestic Product in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.actualitix.com/country/ven/venezuela-public-debt-per-gdp.php|title=Venezuela - Public debt (% of GDP) - 2016|website=en.actualitix.com}}</ref> Instead, the risk premium began to skyrocket at the end of 2014 to a record high of 3,181 points, increasing fears of a possible IMF bailout of Venezuela. The risk premium set a record in August 2017, recording 5,000 basic points exceeding eight times Greece's risk premium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eleconomista.es/economia/noticias/8536568/08/17/Venezuela-dispara-su-riesgo-de-impago-es-ocho-veces-superior-al-de-Grecia.html|title=Venezuela dispara su riesgo de impago: es ocho veces superior al de Grecia - elEconomista.es|first=|last=elEconomista.es|publisher=}}</ref>
== Ratings ==
In the beginning of the crisis, Venezuela's credit ratings were downgraded to "junk territory" or below [[investment grade]] with negative outlooks according to most rating agencies.<ref name=AJdec2013/><ref name=WSJseptDOWNGRADE>{{cite news|last1=Dulaney|first1=Chelsey|last2=Vyas|first2=Kejal|title=S&P Downgrades Venezuela on Worsening Economy Rising Inflation, Economic Pressures Prompt Rating Cut|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/s-p-downgrades-venezuela-on-worsening-economy-1410907125|accessdate=18 September 2014|agency=The Wall Street Journal|date=16 September 2014}}</ref><ref name=MOODYSdec2013/> In a little more than one year, [[Standard and Poor's]] downgraded Venezuela's credit rating three times; from B+ to B in June 2013,<ref name=REUTERSjune2013>{{cite news|last1=Bases|first1=Daniel|title=Update 2 – S&P downgrades Venezuela's sovereign credit rating to B|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/17/venezuela-downgrade-standardandpoors-idUSL2N0ET0Z120130617|accessdate=18 September 2014|agency=Reuters|date=17 June 2013}}</ref> B to B- in December 2013<ref name=AJdec2013>{{cite news|title=S&P cuts Venezuela credit rating to B-minus|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/americas/2013/12/sp-cuts-venezuela-credit-rating-b-minus-2013121323213836870.html|accessdate=18 September 2014|agency=Al Jazeera|date=13 December 2013}}</ref> and from B- to CCC+ in September 2014.<ref name=WSJseptDOWNGRADE/> [[Fitch Ratings]] also lowered each of Venezuela's credit ratings in March 2014 from B+ to B<ref name=REUTERSmarch2013CR>{{cite news|title=Fitch Downgrades Venezuela to 'B'; Outlook Negative|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/03/25/fitch-downgrades-venezuela-to-b-outlook-idUSFit69472120140325|accessdate=18 September 2014|agency=Reuters.|date=25 March 2014}}</ref> and even lower from B to CCC in December 2014.<ref name=FITCHdec2014>{{cite news|title=Fitch Downgrades Venezuela's IDRs to 'CCC'|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/18/fitch-downgrades-venezuelas-idrs-to-ccc-idUSFit87570120141218|accessdate=19 December 2014|agency=Reuters|date=18 December 2014}}</ref> In December 2013, [[Moody's Investors Service]] also downgraded both Venezuela's local (B1) and foreign currency (B2) ratings to Caa1.<ref name=MOODYSdec2013>{{cite web|title=Moody's downgrades Venezuela to Caa1; outlook negative|url=https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-downgrades-Venezuela-to-Caa1-outlook-negative--PR_289285|website=Moody's Investors Service|accessdate=18 September 2014}}</ref> The noted reasons of credit rating changes were the greatly increased likelihood of economic and financial collapse due to the Venezuelan government's policies and an "out of control" inflation rate.<ref name=WSJseptDOWNGRADE/><ref name=MOODYSdec2013/><ref name=REUTERSmarch2013CR/>
In July 2017, Standard & Poor's lowered both the domestic and foreign credit ratings of Venezuela to CCC- due to the increasing risk of default.<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuela Cut Deeper Into Junk by S&P|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-11/venezuela-cut-deeper-into-junk-by-s-p-as-default-risk-surges|accessdate=12 July 2017|work=[[Bloomberg.com]]|date=11 July 2017}}</ref> Fitch Ratings followed suit in August 2017, lowering local and foreign credit ratings to CC.<ref>{{cite news|last1=DeFotis|first1=Dimitra|title=Venezuela Bond Default ‘Probable’ Fitch Downgrade Says|url=http://www.barrons.com/articles/venezuela-bond-default-probable-fitch-downgrade-says-1504129573|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=[[Barron's (newspaper)|Barron's]]|date=30 August 2017}}</ref> In November 2017 Standard & Poor's rated Venezuela in technical default and Fitch ratings rated Venezuela's oil company PDVSA in restrictive default - one rank above full default.{{CN|date=June 2018}}
