A mandatory curfew was ordered beginning April 28 and ended May 3. }} On April 12, 2015, [[Baltimore Police Department]] officers arrested Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old [[African Americans|African American]] resident of [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]]. Gray sustained injuries to his neck and spine while in transport in a police vehicle. On April 18, 2015, after Gray's subsequent coma, the residents of Baltimore protested in front of the Western district police station. Gray [[Death of Freddie Gray|died the following day]], April 19, 2015, a week after the arrest. Further protests were organized after Gray's death became public knowledge, amid the police department's continuing inability to adequately or consistently explain the events following the arrest and the injuries. Spontaneous protests started after the funeral service, although several included violent elements. Civil unrest continued with at least twenty police officers injured, at least 250 people arrested, 285 to 350 businesses damaged, 150 vehicle fires, 60 structure fires,{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/damage-to-businesses-from-baltimore-rioting-estimated-at-9-million/2015/05/13/5848c3fe-f9a8-11e4-a13c-193b1241d51a_story.html |title=Damage to businesses from Baltimore rioting estimated at about $9 million |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=May 13, 2015 |author=Wenger, Yvonne |accessdate=August 14, 2015}} 27 drugstores looted,{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/13/us/after-freddie-gray-death-west-baltimores-police-presence-drops-and-murders-soar.html?ref=todayspaper&_r=3 |title=West Baltimore's Police Presence Drops, and Murders Soar |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 12, 2015 |author=Oppel, Richard A. Jr |accessdate=August 14, 2015}} thousands of police and [[Maryland National Guard]] troops deployed, and with a [[State of emergency#United States|state of emergency]] declared in the city limits of Baltimore.{{cite news|title=Baltimore riots live updates: About 200 arrested after violence, fires sweep city|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-baltimore-freddie-gray-20150427-htmlstory.html|accessdate=April 28, 2015|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=April 28, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Simpson|first1=Ian|last2=Strobel|first2=Warren|title=Thousands of police descend on Baltimore to enforce curfew after riots|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/28/us-usa-police-baltimore-idUSKBN0NI1N720150428|accessdate=April 29, 2015|agency=Reuters|date=April 28, 2015}} The state of emergency was lifted on May 6.{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/05/06/404675117/maryland-governor-lifts-state-of-emergency-in-baltimore |title=Maryland Governor Lifts State Of Emergency In Baltimore |website=NPR.org |date=May 6, 2015 |author=Calamur, Krishnadev |accessdate=August 14, 2015}} The series of protests took place against a historical backdrop of racial and poverty issues in Baltimore according to David M. Ettlin, longtime reporter from The Baltimore Sun, now retired.{{cite web | url=http://baltimorepostexaminer.com/racial-tension-haunts-baltimore-across-chasm-of-45-years/2015/05/05 | title=Racial tension haunts Baltimore across chasm of 45 years | work=Baltimore Post-Examiner | date=May 5, 2015 | accessdate=February 6, 2016 | author=David Ettlin}} On May 1, 2015, Gray's death was ruled by the [[medical examiner]] to be a [[homicide]]. Six officers were charged with various offenses, including second-degree murder, in connection with Gray's death.{{cite news|last1=Blinder|first1=Alan|title=Prosecutors Charge 6 Baltimore Officers in Freddie Gray Death|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/02/us/freddie-gray-autopsy-report-given-to-baltimore-prosecutors.html?_r=0|accessdate=May 1, 2015|newspaper=New York Times|date=May 1, 2015}} Three officers were subsequently [[Acquittal|acquitted]]; in July 2016, following the acquittals, Baltimore City State's Attorney [[Marilyn Mosby]] dropped charges against the remaining three officers.Sherl Gay Stolberg & Jess Bidgood, [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/28/us/charges-dropped-against-3-remaining-officers-in-freddie-gray-case.html All Charges Dropped Against Baltimore Officers in Freddie Gray Case], ''New York Times'' (July 27, 2016). ==Events== ===April 12: Gray's arrest=== On April 12, 2015, Freddie Carlos Gray, Jr., a 25-year-old African-American man, was arrested by the Baltimore City Police Department in the 1700 block of Presbury Street in the [[Sandtown-Winchester, Baltimore|Sandtown-Winchester neighborhood]]. Gray was seen to be in good health at the time of the arrest. While being transported in a police van, Gray sustained injuries to his neck, including his vocal box and spinal cord. He fell into a coma and was taken to a trauma center. The BCPD could not immediately account for the injuries and released contradictory and inconsistent information regarding the timeline of the arrest, transportation and whether Gray had received appropriately prompt medical treatment. On May 23, 2016, officer Edward Nero was found not guilty of all charges against him in connection with the death of Freddie Gray.{{cite web|last1=Fieldstadt|first1=Elisha|title=Officer Charged in Freddie Gray Case, Edward Nero, Not Guilty on All Counts|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/baltimore-unrest/officer-freddie-gray-death-edward-nero-not-guilty-all-counts-n578676|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=May 23, 2016}} Shortly after that, the remaining officers who had not yet stood trial had all charges against them dropped. ===April 18–24: Protests begin=== On April 18, 2015, immediately outside the Western District police station, hundreds of Baltimore citizens protested against the apparent mistreatment of Freddie Gray as well against inadequate and inconsistent information on police actions during the arrest and transport. Gray died at approximately 7am on April 19, 2015.{{Cite web|title = Timeline: Freddie Gray's arrest, death and the aftermath - Baltimore Sun|url = http://data.baltimoresun.com/news/freddie-gray/|website = data.baltimoresun.com|accessdate = 2015-11-18}} Later that day, in response to Gray's death, Baltimore City Police Commissioner, Anthony Batts said, "I extend my deepest sympathies to his family" while also saying, "All Lives Matter" in a nod to the "Black Lives Matter" mantra shouted at protests.{{Cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/freddie-gray/bs-md-freddie-gray-20150419-story.html|title=Freddie Gray dies a week after being injured during arrest|last=Sun|first=Baltimore|website=baltimoresun.com|access-date=2016-05-06}} Protests continued during six nights in Baltimore's streets. On April 21, 2015, the [[Baltimore Police Department|Baltimore City Police Department]] released the identities of the six officers involved in Gray's arrest. That evening, protesters marched from the site of Gray's arrest to the Western District police station. On April 23, two people were arrested.{{cite news|last=Ileto|first=Christine|title=Police Make Arrests; Protests Continue Over Freddie Gray's Death|url=http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2015/04/23/5th-day-of-protests-in-freddie-grays-death-expected/|accessdate=May 5, 2015|work=[[WJZ-TV]]|date=April 23, 2015}} Tensions flared, but according to the [[Baltimore Police Department|Baltimore City Police Department]], the remaining protesters that day were peaceful.{{cite news|last1=Yan|first1=Holly|last2=Fantz|first2=Ashley|last3=Hutcherson|first3=Kimberly|title=Freddie Gray death: Protesters, police scuffle in Baltimore|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/23/us/baltimore-freddie-gray-death/index.html|accessdate=May 5, 2015|work=[[CNN]]|date=April 23, 2015}} On April 24, a coalition of organizations including the ACLU, the NAACP, CASA de Maryland, and Leaders of a Beautiful Struggle requested Governor Larry Hogan to act and address issues of police brutality.{{Cite web|title = Civil rights groups call on Hogan to convene special session|url = http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/bs-md-freddie-gray-hogan-bills-20150424-story.html|website = baltimoresun.com|accessdate = 2015-11-18}} ===April 25: Violence escalates=== [[File:Baltimore Riots Smash McDonalds.webm|thumb|left|thumbtime=13|Rioters breaking the windows of a [[McDonald's]] restaurant on the evening of April 25, 2015]] On April 25, 2015, protests were organized in [[downtown Baltimore]]. Protesters marched from the [[Baltimore City Hall]] to the Inner [[Inner Harbor|Harbor]]. After the final stage of the official protest event, some people became violent, damaging at least five police vehicles and [[criminal rock throwing|pelting police with rocks]].{{cite news|last1=Stolberg|first1=Sheryl Grey|title=National Guard Activated in Baltimore as Police and Youths Clash After Funeral for Freddie Gray|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/28/us/a-call-for-peace-before-freddie-grays-funeral-in-baltimore.html|accessdate=April 28, 2015|work=The New York Times|date=August 27, 2015}} Near [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards]], some groups of violent protesters also smashed storefronts and fought with baseball fans arriving at the stadium for a scheduled game between the [[Baltimore Orioles]] and [[Boston Red Sox|the Boston Red Sox]]. As a result of the violence, those attending the baseball game were forced{{Cite news|url = https://www.si.com/mlb/2015/04/25/baltimore-protests-orioles-camden-yards-fans-remain-inside|title = Fans Asked to Stay Inside Camden Yards due to Baltimore Protests|last = Fiammetta|first = ike|date = April 25, 2015|work = Sports Illustrated|access-date = May 19, 2015|via = Google News}} to remain inside the stadium for their safety.{{cite news|title=Fans at Orioles-Red Sox asked to stay in Camden Yards after violent protest|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/mlb/orioles/2015/04/25/baltimore-orioles-boston-red-sox-camden-yards-freddie-gray-protest/26390977/|accessdate=April 28, 2015|work=[[USA Today]]|date=April 25, 2015}} At least 34 people were arrested during the riots, and six police officers were injured.{{cite news|title = Freddie Gray death: 12 arrested during protests|url = http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/25/us/baltimore-freddie-gray-protest/index.html|publisher = CNN|accessdate = April 25, 2015|date = April 25, 2015|last = Marquez|first = Miguel|last2 = Almasy|first2 = Steve}}Wenger, Yvonne; Campbell, Colin. [http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-city/bs-md-ci-protest-arrests-20150426-story.html City leader calls for peace after 35 arrested, 6 officers injured], ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'', April 26, 2015. J.M. Giordano, a photographer for ''[[Baltimore City Paper]]'', was taking pictures of the protest when he was "swarmed" and beaten by two police officers in [[riot gear]].{{cite news |last = Serpick|first = Evan|title = City Paper photo editor J.M. Giordano beaten by police at Freddie Gray protest|publisher = City Paper (Baltimore)|date = April 26, 2015|url = http://www.citypaper.com/blogs/the-news-hole/bcpnews-city-paper-photo-editor-jm-giordano-beaten-by-police-at-freddie-gray-protest-20150426,0,229974.story|accessdate = April 28, 2015}} Sait Serkan Gurbuz, a [[Reuters]] photographer with visible press credentials, who photographed the scuffle from a public sidewalk, was tackled, handcuffed and walked to the Western District station. He was cited for failure to obey and later released. Subsequently, ''City Paper'' published a video on its website documenting the violence.{{Cite news|title = The Latest: Baltimore mayor calls for peace after protests|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/latest-on-police-custody-death-police-issue-dispersal-order/2015/04/25/c07e7978-ebac-11e4-8581-633c536add4b_story.html|newspaper = The Washington Post|date = April 25, 2015|access-date = April 27, 2015|issn = 0190-8286|last = Associated Press}} During a press conference, Baltimore mayor [[Stephanie Rawlings-Blake]] said, "most protesters were respectful but a small group of agitators intervened". She also stated that "It's a very delicate balancing act. Because while we try to make sure that they were protected from the cars and other things that were going on, we also gave those who wished to destroy space to do that as well. And we worked very hard to keep that balance and to put ourselves in the best position to de-escalate."[http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2015/04/25/baltimore-mayor-gave-those-who-wished-to-destroy-space-to-do-that/ Baltimore Mayor: ‘Gave Those Who Wished to Destroy Space to Do That’], CBS News Baltimore, April 25, 2015 The phrase "we also gave those who wished to destroy space to do that as well" was interpreted by some conservative-leaning news sources{{cite web | url = http://dailycaller.com/2015/04/26/baltimore-mayor-i-wanted-to-give-space-to-those-who-wished-to-destroy-video/ | title = Baltimore Mayor: Space Was Provided To Those Who 'Wished To Destroy' | work = dailycaller.com | date = 2015-04-26 | accessdate = 2015-04-28 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.newsmax.com/Newsfront/Baltimore-riots-mayor-Stephanie-Rawlings-Blake/2015/04/28/id/641206/ | title = Baltimore Mayor Gave Protesters 'Permission to Riot' | work = newsmax.com | date = 2015-04-28 | accessdate = 2015-04-28 }}{{cite web | url = http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2015/04/27/baltimore-mayor-balancing-act-gave-protestors-permission-to-turn-violent/ | title = Baltimore mayor's 'balancing act' gave protestors permission to turn violent | work = foxnews.com | date = 2015-04-27 | accessdate = 2015-04-28 }} as an indication that the mayor was giving permission to protesters to destroy property. Two days later, the mayor's Director of Strategic Planning and Policy, Howard Libit, released a statement clarifying the mayor's remarks: {{Quote|text=What she is saying within this statement was that there was an effort to give the peaceful demonstrators room to conduct their peaceful protests on Saturday. Unfortunately, as a result of providing the peaceful demonstrators with the space to share their message, that also meant that those seeking to incite violence also had the space to operate. The police sought to balance the rights of the peaceful demonstrators against the need to step in against those who were seeking to create violence. The mayor is not saying that she asked police to give space to people who sought to create violence. Any suggestion otherwise would be a misinterpretation of her statement.{{cite web | url = http://content.govdelivery.com/accounts/MDBALT/bulletins/10158de | title = Rawlings-Blake Administration Issues Statement Regarding Mayor's Comments on the Rights of Protesters | author = Kevin Harris | date = April 27, 2015 | accessdate = April 28, 2015 }}}} {{gallery|align=center|title=Documentaries|lines=3 |File:Voices_Of_The_Freddie_Gray_Protest-_Part_1.webm|Part 1 of a documentary video of the protests produced for [[WEAA]] during the day of April 25, before rioting started |File:Voices_Of_The_Freddie_Gray_Protest-_Part_2.webm|Part 2 of the [[WEAA]] documentary video |File:Baltimore- April 25th, 2015.webm|An independent documentary video of the protests during the day of April 25, before rioting started}} ===April 27=== ====Funeral==== A funeral service was held for Freddie Gray at the New Shiloh Baptist Church on April 27 at 11 a.m., after a one-hour public viewing.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/freddie-gray-funeral-held-amid-alleged-credible-threat/story?id=30610298|title=Freddie Gray Funeral Held Amid Alleged Credible Threat to Law Enforcement|publisher=ABC News|date=April 27, 2015}} A large attendance included civil rights leaders, families of other people killed by police, and politicians including Congressman [[Elijah Cummings]], Cabinet Secretary Broderick Johnson, White House adviser Heather Foster, and Elias Alcantara of the [[Office of Intergovernmental Affairs]].{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/27/us/baltimore-freddie-gray-funeral/|title=Freddie Gray funeral draws White House officials, Eric Garner's family|publisher=CNN|first1=Holly |last1=Yan |first2=Ashley |last2=Fantz|date=April 27, 2015}} Gray is buried at Woodlawn Cemetery in [[Baltimore County, Maryland]].{{cite news|last1=Marbella|first=Jean|last2=Pitts|first2=Jonathan|title=Friends, family bid farewell to Freddie Gray|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-city/bs-md-ci-freddie-gray-funeral-20150427-story.html#page=2|accessdate=May 6, 2015|work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|date=April 28, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Smialowski|first=Brendan|title=Freddie Gray is buried at Woodlawn Cemetery in Baltimore, Maryland, on April 27, 2015|url=https://news.yahoo.com/photos/freddie-gray-buried-woodlawn-cemetery-baltimore-maryland-april-photo-011134505.html|accessdate=May 6, 2015|work=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=April 27, 2015}} ====Preemptive actions==== A photograph of the April 25 rioters standing on a Baltimore police car was superimposed with the text "All HighSchools Monday @3 We Are Going To Purge From [[Mondawmin Mall|Mondawmin]] To The Ave, Back To Downtown #Fdl" ("Purge" being a reference to [[The Purge (film series)|the film series]])[https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CDnmRHqWgAMhaHJ.jpg:large Image] cited in ''The New York Times'' [https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/04/24/us/freddie-gray-and-the-baltimore-police-department-timeline.html "Mapping the Clashes"] and distributed on social media{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/04/24/us/freddie-gray-and-the-baltimore-police-department-timeline.html|title=Mapping the Clashes Between Baltimore Police and Protesters|work=The New York Times|date=April 27, 2015}} and as flyers.{{cite web|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/2048326/baltimore-purge-flyers-reportedly-called-for-violence/|title=Baltimore Purge: Flyers Imitating 'The Purge' Reportedly Called For Violence, Contributed To Riots|publisher=Inquistr|date=April 28, 2015}} In response, Mondawmin Mall was closed at 2:15 p.m. and police in riot gear were deployed to the area. In preparation for the 'purge' police shut down the Mondawmin metro stop and also blockaded many of the nearby streets.{{cite web|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2015/04/how-baltimore-riots-began-mondawmin-purge|title=Eyewitnesses: The Baltimore Riots Didn't Start the Way You Think|work=Mother Jones|first1=Sam |last1=Brodey |first2=Jenna |last2=McLaughlin |date=April 28, 2015}} As a result, students from [[Frederick Douglass High School (Baltimore, Maryland)|Frederick Douglass High School]], which is across the street from Mondawmin Mall, had considerable difficulty leaving the area via public transportation when their classes ended an hour after the "purge" began, and contributed to the swelling crowd.{{cite web|url=http://news.wypr.org/post/douglass-students-say-they-got-bad-rap|title=Douglass Students Say They Got A Bad Rap |publisher=WYPR|author=P. Kenneth Burns|date=April 30, 2015}} According to eyewitness reports, expecting the "purge" to start at 3 p.m., Baltimore police pre-emptively de-boarded all buses going through the area, shut down the nearby [[Mondawmin (Baltimore Metro Subway station)|Mondawmin Metro station]] and cordoned off the area around the mall. Eyewitnesses saw police detain students in that general area. The police, in full riot gear, detained the students for a full half-hour before the first brick was thrown. Meghann Harris, a teacher in the Baltimore school system, said on [[Facebook]], "If I were a Douglass[sic] student that just got trapped in the middle of a minefield BY cops without any way to get home and completely in harm's way, I'd be ready to pop off, too."{{cite web | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-fix/wp/2015/04/28/the-baltimore-riots-and-the-significant-distrust-of-police-in-america/ | title=Just one in four urban black Americans trust the police | work=The Washington Post | date=April 28, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015 | first=Philip |last=Bump}} Other closings in preparation or response to the riot included the [[University of Maryland Baltimore]], which closed its campus in downtown Baltimore at 2:00 p.m. citing a police warning regarding "activities (that) may be potentially violent and UMB could be in the path of any violence", [[Baltimore City Community College]], [[Coppin State University]], the [[Lexington Market]], the [[National Aquarium in Baltimore|National Aquarium]], and the [[Enoch Pratt Free Library]] system.{{cite news |title=National Guard Called Out in Baltimore as Police and Youths Clash After Funeral for Freddie Gray |last=Stolberg |first=Sheryl Gay |work=The New York Times |date=April 27, 2015 |accessdate=April 27, 2015 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/28/us/a-call-for-peace-before-freddie-grays-funeral-in-baltimore.html}} The [[Kinetic sculpture race#East Coast Championship in Baltimore|Baltimore Kinetic Sculpture Race]] was rescheduled from May 2 to June 14.{{cite news|title=AVAM's Kinetic Sculpture Race rescheduled for June 14|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/bthesite/bal-avams-kinetic-sculpture-race-rescheduled-for-june-14-20150512-story.html|accessdate=October 3, 2015|work=The Baltimore Sun}} A [[Baltimore Orioles]] baseball game against the [[Chicago White Sox]] scheduled for the evening at [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards]], and the first of a three-game series, was also postponed due to the unrest.{{cite news|title=Tonight's Orioles game postponed amid violence downtown|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/orioles/blog/bal-as-turmoil-currently-envelops-the-city-tonights-orioles-game-against-the-chicago-white-sox-is-stille-20150427-story.html|accessdate=April 27, 2015|work=The Baltimore Sun}} ====Spread of violence==== Initially 75–100 people who appeared to be high school students began throwing bricks and bottles at police near Mondawmin Mall{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/confrontation-at-mondawmin-mall-led-2015-4|title=A confrontation between cops and teenagers kicked off the horrifying Baltimore riots|publisher=Business Insider|first=Eric |last=Fuchs|date=April 28, 2015}} after police refused high school students access to their primary means of getting home (the transportation hub at Mondawmin Mall),{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/27/police-throw-rocks-baltimore_n_7156614.html|title=Police Throw Rocks Back At Protesters In Baltimore|work=The Huffington Post|first=Nick |last=Wing|date=April 28, 2015}} while ordering them to disperse and go home. The violence rapidly spread, and by later that day two patrol cars were destroyed and fifteen officers were injured.{{Cite news|title =Baltimore police, protesters clash; 15 officers hurt|url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/04/27/baltimore-credible-threat/26454875/|newspaper = USA Today|date = April 27, 2015|access-date = April 27, 2015|last = Bacon|first = John}} A police cruiser was destroyed, and some officers suffered broken bones.{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldtribune.com/article/20150427/WIRE/150429710|title=7 officers wounded in Baltimore protests|publisher=HeraldTribune.com|accessdate=April 28, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Bacon|first1=John|title=Baltimore police, protesters clash; 15 officers hurt|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/04/27/baltimore-credible-threat/26454875/|accessdate=April 30, 2015|publisher=CNN|date=April 28, 2015}} A [[CVS Pharmacy]] location in West Baltimore was looted and burned by rioters;{{cite news | title = Baltimore protests turn violent; police injured| last = Ford | first = Dana| publisher = CNN| date = April 27, 2015| accessdate = April 27, 2015| url = http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/27/us/baltimore-unrest/index.html}} no one in the CVS was hurt because employees had been evacuated before the CVS was looted and burned,{{cite web | url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/04/27/news/companies/cvs-balitmore-riot-looting/index.html | title=CVS got employees out of Baltimore store just before looting and fire | publisher=CNN | date=April 27, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015}} but a fire hose used later to put out the CVS fire was punctured by a rioter.{{cite web | url=http://www.theblaze.com/stories/2015/04/27/man-punctures-fire-hose-as-firefighters-attempt-to-put-out-cvs-fire-in-baltimore/ | title=US Man Punctures Fire Hose As Firefighters Attempt to Put out CVS Fire in Baltimore | work=The Blaze | date=April 27, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015 | first=Oliver | last=Darcy}} In East Baltimore, the Mary Harvin Senior Center, an under-construction senior housing and services project, burned to the ground; it was rebuilt and opened in April 2016.http://www.wbaltv.com/news/mary-harvin-senior-center-reopens-year-after-fire/39245836 ===April 28=== ====Morning==== [[File:Maryland National Guard (17285160576).jpg|thumb|right|A soldier from 1st Battalion, [[175th Infantry Regiment (United States)|175th Infantry Regiment]] keeps watch in front of [[Baltimore City Hall]] on April 28]] At about 6:00 a.m., Baltimore television showed firefighters putting out fires and residents cleaning up after the overnight rioting.{{cite news|title=LATEST ON POLICE-CUSTODY DEATH: OBAMA: NO EXCUSE FOR RIOT |url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2015/The-latest-on-Baltimore-police-custody-death-More-than-150-fires-in-Baltimore-city-says/id-0b32a37d8b0440b8a444403f5c7ad647 |accessdate=April 28, 2015 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=April 28, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150428170503/http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2015/The-latest-on-Baltimore-police-custody-death-More-than-150-fires-in-Baltimore-city-says/id-0b32a37d8b0440b8a444403f5c7ad647 |archivedate=April 28, 2015 }} Soldiers from the 1st Battalion, 175th Infantry Regiment, Maryland Army National Guard arrived in Baltimore to provide security to vital infrastructure and to give additional support to police. At about 7:35 a.m., the Baltimore mayor's office reported that there were 144 vehicle fires, 15 structural fires, and nearly 200 arrests. One person had been badly hurt due to an arson.{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/28/us/baltimore-riots/ | title=Baltimore riots: Security beefed up, cleanup starts after looting, fires | publisher=CNN | date=April 28, 2015 | accessdate=April 28, 2015}} At 8:25 a.m., it was announced that Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan was temporarily moving his office from Annapolis to Baltimore and that Hogan would visit scenes around Baltimore. At approximately 9:00 a.m., Hogan visited an intersection on West Baltimore that was heavily affected by the rioting with damaged vehicles and a looted convenience store, thanking those in the area for help cleaning up the streets. In one incident that went viral during the previous night, Baltimore mother, Toya Graham, repeatedly struck and berated her son on TV for throwing rocks at police. Graham stated that she didn't want her son to end up like Freddie Gray, but also that he shouldn't seek justice by rioting.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/local/wp/2015/04/28/woman-called-mom-of-the-year-after-beating-a-young-man-out-of-baltimore-riots/|title=Mom filmed berating her son at Baltimore riots didn't 'want him to be a Freddie Gray'|work=The Washington Post}}{{cite news|last=Reimer|first=Susan|title=Send in the moms to stop Freddie Gray rioting|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/opinion/oped/bs-ed-reimer-riot-mom-freddie-gray-20150430-column.html|accessdate=May 7, 2015|work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|date=April 30, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Rosenbaum|first=Sophia|last2=Fredericks|first2=Bob|title=Baltimore Mom of the Year: 'I don't want him to be a Freddie Gray'|url=https://nypost.com/2015/04/28/baltimore-mom-of-the-year-i-dont-want-him-to-be-a-freddie-gray/|accessdate=May 7, 2015|work=[[The New York Post]]|date=April 28, 2015}} At 11:15 a.m. on April 28, Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts praised Graham, stating, "I wish I had more parents that took charge of their kids out there."{{cite web|url=http://www.abc2news.com/news/crime-checker/baltimore-city-crime/video-mom-beats-child-for-throwing-rocks-at-baltimore-police|title=VIDEO: Mom beats child for throwing rocks at Baltimore Police|publisher=WMAR|access-date=April 29, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429121303/http://www.abc2news.com/news/crime-checker/baltimore-city-crime/video-mom-beats-child-for-throwing-rocks-at-baltimore-police|archive-date=April 29, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://7online.com/news/video-angry-baltimore-mom-beats-son-suspected-of-rioting/684791/|title=VIDEO: Angry mom beats son suspected of rioting in Baltimore|publisher=ABC7 New York}} Baltimore County police spokesman Cpl. John Wachter also announced that [[Security Square Mall]] was going to be closed for the rest of the day following the spreading of rumors that planned actions were going to occur there. The Social Security Administration and the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services also closed.{{cite web | url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-county/bs-md-co-security-closed-20150428-story.html | title=Baltimore County squashes rumors of another 'purge' outside city | work=Baltimore Sun | date=April 28, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015}} ====Afternoon and evening==== At 12:00 p.m. in the area where Freddie Gray was arrested, volunteers numbering in the hundreds were seen cleaning up debris left from the rioting. Police blocked off some of the area to assist with the cleanup while hardware stores in the neighborhood donated trash bags and brooms and city workers drove in trucks to carry away piles of trash and shattered glass. At 12:55 p.m., President Obama stated that there have been too many worrying interactions between police and black citizens, but said there was "no excuse" for the violence of rioters in Baltimore. At about 1:30 p.m., crowds gathered at a damaged drug store where Rev. [[Jesse Jackson]] was visiting, with Jackson stating, "It was painful because it destroyed a lot of neighborhood businesses and hurt a lot of people, but the violence is driven by that alienation." At a 2:30 p.m. speaking event by Capt. Eric Kowalczyk discussing incidents that occurred on April 27, demonstrators gathered peacefully, though one individual was arrested and pepper spray was used when some protesters became disorderly. At 3:00 p.m., Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake took back comments calling rioters "thugs", saying that occasionally, "my little anger interpreter gets the best of me." Baltimore religious leaders announced that 14 churches throughout the city were open to give food to children that relied on schools to provide daily meals.{{cite news|title=LATEST ON POLICE-CUSTODY DEATH: COURT WAITS COULD INCREASE |url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2015/The-latest-on-Baltimore-police-custody-death-More-than-150-fires-in-Baltimore-city-says/id-0b32a37d8b0440b8a444403f5c7ad647 |accessdate=April 29, 2015 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=April 29, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429101411/http://www.apnewsarchive.com/2015/The-latest-on-Baltimore-police-custody-death-More-than-150-fires-in-Baltimore-city-says/id-0b32a37d8b0440b8a444403f5c7ad647 |archivedate=April 29, 2015 }} At 8:30 p.m., the CEO of Baltimore City Public Schools, Gregory Thornton, announced that Baltimore City Public School classes and after-school events would occur on April 29. Just before 9:00 p.m., several hundred protesters gathered around the CVS store that was looted, with some individuals separating the protesters and police, while a local pastor told demonstrators over a loud speaker to respect the curfew, saying, "Let's show the world, because the eyes of the world are on Baltimore right now." A police spokesman, Captain Eric Kowalczyk, stated that authorities were attempting to inform Baltimore residents of the 10:00 p.m. curfew in multiple ways, through police in patrol cars, sending messages through a police helicopter over the city and by calling residents through a [[Reverse 911]] system. [[File:Baltimore riot police VOA.jpg|thumb|left|Baltimore riot policemen form a line to push back protesters and media members on April 28]] At 10:15 p.m., hundreds of demonstrators, some throwing bottles at police, remained in the streets while police in riot gear began to move the crowds with speakers from helicopters overhead broadcasting, "You must go home. You cannot remain here. You will be subject to arrest." Tensions began to grow after individuals began to throw objects at police. Shortly after 10:30 p.m., smoke bombs or fireworks were thrown from the crowd and police equipped with riot shields began to slowly advance on the gathering with some people beginning to disperse. At 10:32 p.m., Baltimore Police tweeted that "Officers are now deploying pepper balls at the aggressive crowd". They then tweeted at 10:34 p.m. "People who remain on the street – who do not meet the exceptions – are now in violation of the emergency curfew" with police moving across the intersection and the crowd dispersing down side streets away from the area. At 10:50 p.m., military vehicles were seen driving through the streets to disperse the remaining crowd numbered with dozens of people. At 11:00 p.m., the CVS intersection was clear except for police and media workers who were exempt from the curfew. At 11:40 p.m., Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts stated that the curfew seemed to work and that ten people were arrested; seven for violating the curfew, two people for looting and one for disorderly conduct. Between start of curfew and late night, thirty-five people, including one juvenile, had been arrested for violating the curfew.{{cite news|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/4/29/baltimore-schools-set-to-reopen-after-quiet-night.html|title=Second Night of Baltimore Curfew Arrives Quietly|work=Al Jazeera America|date=April 29, 2015|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} ===April 29 – May 3=== After the riots, many small business owners struggled to clean up.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2015/05/03/riots-rattle-some-baltimore-homeowners-key-to-urban-revitalization/|title=Riots rattle Baltimore homeowners, merchants key to urban revitalization|author=Joseph Weber|work=Fox News}} Over 200 small businesses were unable to reopen by April 29.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/baltimore-riot-damage-adds-burden-small-businesses-30707975|title=Baltimore Riot Damage Adds Burden to Small Businesses|author=ABC News|work=ABC News}} Residents of all ages, genders, and races came together to help clean Baltimore's streets.{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/29/us/gallery/baltimore-protests-cleanup/ |title=Cleaning up after Baltimore riots |newspaper=CNN |date=April 29, 2015 |author= |accessdate=May 7, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Keady|first=Cameron|title=Baltimore Residents Come Together To Clean Up City After Riots|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/28/baltimore-community-cleanup_n_7162666.html|accessdate=May 11, 2015|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=April 28, 2015}} Eighteen were arrested for curfew violations on April 29.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/baltimore-streets-quiet-as-residents-obey-curfew-after-riots-1430302760|title=Protests Resume in Baltimore With Hundreds Marching on City Hall - WSJ|publisher=wsj.com|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} [[File:Maryland National Guard (17145635149).jpg|thumb|Protesters gathered in front of [[Baltimore City Hall]] on April 30]] From April 29-May 3, 2015 FBI surveillance aircraft used [[Forward looking infrared|FLIR]] cameras to record video of civil unrest. In August 2016, 18 hours of footage was released following a FOIA request from the [[American Civil Liberties Union]].{{cite web|title=FBI Dumps 18 Hours of Spy Plane Footage From Black Lives Matter Protests|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/read/black-lives-matter-spy-plane-fbi}}{{cite web |title=Protests in Baltimore, Maryland 2015, Aerial Surveillance Footage|url=https://vault.fbi.gov/protests-in-baltimore-maryland-2015/unedited-versions-of-video-surveillance-footage}} By April 30, over forty [[Korean American|South Korean]]-[[History of the Koreans in Baltimore|owned businesses]] had been damaged by the riots.{{cite news |author= |title=Count of damaged Korean-owned Baltimore businesses rises to 40 |url=http://www.koreatimesus.com/count-of-damaged-korean-owned-baltimore-businesses-rises-to-40/ |newspaper=Korean Times |date=April 30, 2015 |access-date=June 16, 2015 }}
{{cite news |first=Paul |last=Duggan |first2=Jennifer |last2=Jenkins |agency=Washington Post |title=After the Baltimore riots, a Korean storeowner picks up the pieces |url=http://www.columbiatribune.com/news/perspectives/after-the-baltimore-riots-a-korean-storeowner-picks-up-the/article_c499c474-7f6d-5e25-a1a3-563df3633cb5.html |newspaper=Columbia Daily Tribune |location=Columbia, Missouri |date=May 24, 2015 |access-date=June 16, 2015 }}
{{cite journal |first=Dennis P. |last=Halpin |title=The Other Racial Divide |url=http://m.weeklystandard.com/articles/other-racial-divide_946670.html |journal=The Weekly Standard |date=May 25, 2015 |access-date=June 16, 2015 |volume=20 |issue=35 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150617061025/http://m.weeklystandard.com/articles/other-racial-divide_946670.html |archive-date=June 17, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}
{{cite news |first=David |last=Collins |title=Korean businesses especially hard hit by looters |url=http://www.wbaltv.com/news/korean-businesses-especially-hard-hit-by-looters/32667308 |newspaper=WBAL |location=Baltimore, Maryland |date=April 30, 2015 |access-date=June 16, 2015 }} [[Chinese American]] and [[Arab American]] owned stores were also targeted, with looters directed by African American gangs towards those businesses.{{cite news |first=Ron |last=Nixon |title=Amid Violence, Factions and Messages Converge in a Weary and Unsettled Baltimore |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/28/us/amid-violence-factions-and-messages-converge-in-a-weary-and-unsettled-baltimore.html?_r=1 |newspaper=New York Times |date=April 27, 2015 |access-date=June 16, 2015 }}{{cite news |first=Nurith |last=Aizenmen |title=Baltimore Unrest Reveals Tensions Between African-Americans And Asians |url=https://www.npr.org/2015/04/30/403231749/baltimore-unrest-reveals-tensions-between-african-americans-and-asian-owned-busi |newspaper=NPR |date=April 30, 2015 |access-date=June 16, 2015 }} Forty people were arrested for such night violations on May 1.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/victory-rally-arrests-made-violators-baltimore-curfew/story?id=30761806|title=After 'Victory Rally,' Arrests Made of Violators of Baltimore Curfew - ABC News|publisher=abcnews.go.com|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} After the largest peaceful rally on Saturday, May 2, 2015, 46 people were arrested during the night time curfew.{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-baltimore-lifts-curfew-20150503-story.html |title=As Baltimore curfew ends, celebratory crowds peacefully gather |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=May 3, 2015 |author=W.J. Hennigan |accessdate=May 7, 2015}} One person arrested on May 2 was News2Share journalist Ford Fischer. He was handcuffed and initially charged with violating curfew, despite the police confirming that "he's credentialed media."{{cite web|url=http://www.mintpressnews.com/goodbye-first-amendment-reporter-handcuffed-slammed-on-pavement-detained-cited-for-filming-baltimore-police-chase-ford-fischer/205302/|title=VIDEO: Reporter Handcuffed, Slammed On Pavement & Detained For Filming Baltimore Police Chase}} After confirming the charge as "curfew violation" to another journalist, they changed it to a civil citation for "Disorderly Conduct." As of May 21, he still faces that citation.{{cite web|url=http://photographyisnotacrime.com/2015/05/journalist-arrested-trying-to-record-baltimore-police-making-arrest/|title=Journalist Arrested Trying to Record Baltimore Police Making Arrest}} This all came after the police department had confirmed that media are exempt from the curfew via Twitter.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/baltimorepolice/status/593596599672172544|title= Baltimore Police Tweet}} The night curfew on the city was lifted on May 3.{{cite web|first1=Ben |last1=Nuckols |first2=David |last2= Dishneau |date=May 3, 2015 |title=Baltimore mayor lifts curfew 6 days after riots|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/b7d01c00ffd64ce9b0caa0925b424193/baltimore-relieved-charges-weary-curfew |work=Associated Press}} Meanwhile, all charges against violators were dropped. It was found that in section 14-107 of the state's public safety code, only the governor and not the mayor has the authority to issue a curfew. It was decided that the arrests of violators were punishment enough. Those who committed violations of the law other than curfew violations have still been prosecuted. The Maryland National Guard withdrew completely from Baltimore on May 4.{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-city/bs-md-ci-curfew-lifted-20150503-story.html#page=1|title=Baltimore moves on as curfew is lifted, National Guard leaves|author=Scott Dance |author2=Chris Kaltenbach|date=May 3, 2015|work=Baltimore Sun}} ===Result of investigation=== Initially, the [[Baltimore Police Department]] suspended six officers with pay pending an investigation of Gray's death.http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/21/us/baltimore-freddie-gray-death/index.html The six officers involved in the arrest were identified as Lieutenant Brian Rice, Sergeant Alicia White, Officer William Porter, Officer Garrett Miller, Officer Edward Nero, and Officer Caesar Goodson.Miller, Jayne. [http://m.wbaltv.com/news/charging-documents-freddie-gray-ran-from-police/32468120 6 officers suspended in Freddie Gray case], [[WBAL-TV|WBAL]], April 20, 2015. Retrieved April 30, 2015. On April 24, 2015, Police Commissioner Anthony Batts said, "We know our police employees failed to get him medical attention in a timely manner multiple times."{{Cite web|title = Police: Freddie Gray didn't get timely medical care after arrest|url = http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/24/us/baltimore-freddie-gray-death/index.html|publisher = CNN|accessdate = April 24, 2015|last = Payne|first = Ed|last2 = Almasy|first2 = Steve|last3 = Pearson|first3 = Michael|date = April 24, 2015}} Batts also acknowledged police did not follow procedure when they failed to buckle Gray in the van while he was being transported to the police station. The [[U.S. Department of Justice]] also opened an investigation into the case.{{Cite web|title = Feds investigating Baltimore man's death in police custody|url = http://www.cbsnews.com/videos/feds-investigating-baltimore-mans-death-in-police-custody/|publisher = CBS News|accessdate = April 22, 2015|last = Boswell|first = Craig|date = April 21, 2015}} ==Charges filed, acquittals, and charges dropped== On May 1, 2015, after receiving a medical examiner's report ruling Gray's death a [[homicide]], state prosecutors said that they had probable cause to file criminal charges against the six officers involved. Mosby said that the Baltimore police had acted illegally and that "No crime had been committed [by Freddie Gray]".{{cite web|url= https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/may/01/baltimore-freddie-gray-death |title= Freddie Gray death: cries of 'justice' in Baltimore after six officers charged |date= May 1, 2015 |access-date= May 1, 2015 |work= The Guardian |first1= Jon |last1=Swaine |first2= Oliver |last2=Laughland |first3= Raya |last3=Jalabi}} Mosby said that Gray "suffered a critical neck injury as a result of being handcuffed, shackled by his feet and unrestrained inside the BPD wagon."{{cite web|title=6 Baltimore Police Officers Charged in Freddie Gray Death|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/02/us/freddie-gray-autopsy-report-given-to-baltimore-prosecutors.html|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/01/us-usa-police-baltimore-idUSKBN0NL1GO20150501|title=Six Baltimore police officers face murder, other charges in death of black man|agency=Reuters|accessdate=May 1, 2015}} Mosby said officers had "failed to establish probable cause for Mr. Gray's arrest, as no crime had been committed",{{cite web|first1=Alan |last1=Blinder |first2=Richard |last2=Perez-Pena|title=6 Baltimore Police Officers Charged in Freddie Gray Death|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/02/us/freddie-gray-autopsy-report-given-to-baltimore-prosecutors.html|website=New York Times|accessdate=May 1, 2015|date=May 1, 2015}} and charged officers with [[false imprisonment]], because Gray was carrying a [[pocket knife]] of legal size, and not the switchblade police claimed he had possessed at the time of his arrest.{{cite web|title=Freddie Gray: Baltimore police to face criminal charges|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-32554371|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=May 1, 2015|date=May 1, 2015}} All six officers were taken into custody and processed at Baltimore Central Booking and Intake Center.{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-city/bs-md-ci-freddie-gray-mosby-presser-0502-20150501-story.html#page=1|title=Six officers charged in death of Freddie Gray|work=The Baltimore Sun|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Six officers charged in death of Freddie Gray|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-city/bs-md-ci-freddie-gray-mosby-presser-0502-20150501-story.html#page=1|work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|accessdate=May 1, 2015}} The trial of Officer William G. Porter, a black officer and the first of the six charged officers to go to trial, ended in a mistrial.{{cite web|title=Prosecutors to appeal judge's order blocking Porter testimony in trials of other officers|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/freddie-gray/bs-md-ci-prosecution-appeal-20160205-story.html|work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|accessdate=Feb 6, 2016}} The Prosecution had intended to have Porter testify against both his supervisor on the day, Sgt. Alicia White, and the driver of the van, Officer Caesar Goodson Jr. The trials ran into significant delays due to multiple motions being filed by both sides in the cases. On May 23, 2016, Officer Edward Nero was found not guilty on all four counts he was charged with, including two counts of misconduct in office, misdemeanor reckless endangerment, and misdemeanor assault in the second degree.{{cite web|last1=Fenton|first1=Justin|last2=Rector|first2=Kevin|title=Freddie Gray case: Baltimore Police Officer Edward Nero found not guilty of all charges|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/freddie-gray/bs-md-ci-nero-verdict-20160521-story.html|website=baltimoresun.com|publisher=The Baltimore Sun|accessdate=31 May 2016|date=May 23, 2016}} In addition to Nero, two others officers were subsequently [[Acquittal|acquitted]]. In July 2016, following the acquittals, Baltimore City State's Attorney [[Marilyn Mosby]] dropped charges against Porter and the remaining two officers. ==Related protests== [[File:NYC Police surrounding protesters at 2015 Flatiron District protests.png|thumb|right|Policemen surround protesters at East 19th Street in [[New York City]].]] On April 29, 2015, protesters marched through [[New York City]], blocking off traffic in key areas, including the [[Holland Tunnel]] and [[West Side Highway]].{{cite web | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/nyc-protests-disrupt-holland-tunnel-west-side-highway-article-1.2204282 | title=Protesters clash with NYPD, disrupt Holland Tunnel and West Side Highway in bid to support Baltimore activists | work=Daily News|location=New York | date=April 29, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015}} Carmen Perez, director of the criminal justice reform group Justice League, said, "It's all about solidarity, We're here to spread the message of peace from Baltimore's initial protests."{{cite news |first1=Benjamin |last1=Mueller |first2=John |last2=Surico |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/30/nyregion/hundreds-march-in-manhattan-to-protest-the-death-of-freddie-gray.html?_r=0 |title=Over 100 Arrested as New Yorkers Protest the Death of Freddie Gray |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 30, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015}} More than 100 people were arrested,{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Baltimore-Unity-Rally-New-York-City-Union-Square-Protests-301750981.html|title=More Than 100 Arrested in Freddie Gray Protests in NYC: Sources|work=NBC New York}} and the police did not allow the protest to take form before making arrests.{{cite web |url=http://gothamist.com/2015/04/30/nypd_lrad_police_state_fascism.php#photo-5 |title=NYPD Cracks Down Hard On Baltimore Solidarity "Shut It Down" Protest |publisher=Gothamist |date=April 30, 2015 |accessdate=April 30, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150430191520/http://gothamist.com/2015/04/30/nypd_lrad_police_state_fascism.php#photo-5 |archivedate=April 30, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} Anti-police brutality protests were also held in [[Denver]] in solidarity with the Baltimore protests. Eleven people were arrested on April 29, 2015 following physical altercations in which police used pepper spray on protesters who rallied around [[Colfax Avenue]] and Broadway street. The confrontation occurred shortly after 7 p.m. when an officer was knocked off his motorcycle by a protester and assaulted by five others. Police reported force was used in response to the incident. By 7:40 p.m., Broadway street was cleared for traffic as protesters relocated to the 16th Street Mall.{{cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_28016764/protesters-march-near-jail-downtown-denver|title=Police User Pepper Spray on Downtown Protesters, 11 Arrested|newspaper=The Denver Post |author1=Joe Rubino |author2=John Frank |date=April 29, 2015|accessdate=April 30, 2015}} There were also solidarity protests in the cities of [[Ann Arbor]],{{cite web|url=http://www.michigandaily.com/news/ferguson-protest/|accessdate=May 14, 2015|title=Ann Arbor community members protest police brutality|work=Michigan Daily|date=May 4, 2015}} [[Albuquerque]],{{cite news|last1=Goldsmith|first1=Alex|title=Albuquerque's 'Baltimore' protests stay peaceful|url=http://krqe.com/2015/04/29/albuquerques-baltimore-protests-stay-peaceful/|accessdate=May 4, 2015|work=KRQE|date=April 29, 2015}} [[Boston]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2015/04/29/boston-rally-planned-support-baltimore-freddie-gray-protesters/wMVWtOMcqyw3VJfZIWmNfO/story.html|title=Boston demonstrators marching in support of Baltimore's Freddie Gray protesters – Metro – The Boston Globe|work=BostonGlobe.com}} [[Cincinnati]],{{cite web|authors=Ellis, Ralph; Payne, Ed; St. Claire, Pat|title=In Philadelphia, police clash with supporters of Baltimore protests|publisher=CNN|date=April 30, 2015|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/30/us/nationwide-freddie-gray-protests/|accessdate=April 30, 2015}} [[Minneapolis]],{{cite web|url=http://minnesota.cbslocal.com/2015/04/29/blacklivesmatter-to-protest-at-gold-medal-park/|title=#BlackLivesMatter Protesters March Through Minneapolis|work=WCCO-TV}} [[Oakland]],{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/crime-courts/ci_28002594/oakland-protesters-marching-solidarity-baltimore-told-disperse-late|title=Oakland: Protesters marching in solidarity with Baltimore told to disperse late Monday|work=Mercury News}} [[Philadelphia]],{{cite news|url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2015/04/30/rally-planned-at-philadelphia-city-hall-in-solidarity-with-baltimore-protests/|title=Rally, March Held In Philadelphia In Solidarity With Baltimore Protests|work=[[KYW-TV]]}} [[Seattle]],{{cite web|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/seattle-demonstrators-support-protests-in-baltimore/|title=Seattle demonstrators support protests in Baltimore|work=The Seattle Times}} and [[Washington, D.C.]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/301761001.html|title=Demonstrators Take to DC Streets, Support Baltimore Protest|work=NBC4 Washington}} ==Reactions== ===Preventive actions=== ====Government actions==== At a press conference in the evening, the mayor announced there would be a citywide curfew of 10:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. starting April 28.{{cite web| title = Baltimore mayor orders curfew; 'thugs' trying to tear down city, she says| last = Muskal | first = Michael| last2 = Hennigan | first2 = W.J.| work = Los Angeles Times| date = April 27, 2015| accessdate = April 27, 2015| url = http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-freddie-gray-funeral-baltimore-20150427-story.html#page=1}}{{cite web| title = Violent clashes flare in Baltimore after Freddie Gray funeral | agency = Associated Press| publisher = Al Jazeera| date = April 27, 2015| accessdate = April 27, 2015| url = http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/4/27/freddie-gray-protests-violence-police.html}}{{cite news| title = Baltimore Mayor Imposes Curfew, Says 'Thugs' Trying To Tear Down City| agency = Associated Press| publisher = CBS Baltimore| date = April 27, 2015| accessdate = April 27, 2015| url = http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2015/04/27/baltimore-mayor-imposes-curfew-says-thugs-trying-to-tear-down-city/}} The Baltimore solicitor's office stated that a limitation of the curfew to only certain neighborhoods could potentially be viewed as racial discrimination.{{cite web |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/politics/bs-md-ci-mayor-curfew-authority-20150511-story.html |title=Mayor's authority to impose curfew questioned |newspaper=The Baltimore Sun |date=May 11, 2015 |author=Justin Fenton |accessdate=July 12, 2015}} Neighboring Anne Arundel and Baltimore Counties cancelled school field trips and activities scheduled in Baltimore City until May 3.{{cite web|title=Concerns over violence leads to area closings in Baltimore |last=Staff |first=WMAR |publisher=WMAR |accessdate=April 27, 2015 |url=http://www.abc2news.com/news/region/baltimore-city/university-of-maryland-baltimore-closing-early |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150430150259/http://www.abc2news.com/news/region/baltimore-city/university-of-maryland-baltimore-closing-early |archivedate=April 30, 2015 }}{{cite web| title = Gov. declares state of emergency; activates National Guard| publisher = WBAL-TV| date = April 27, 2015| accessdate = April 27, 2015| url = http://www.wbaltv.com/news/downtown-businesses-organizations-close-early-monday/32595778}} Officials also announced that Baltimore's city schools would be closed on Tuesday.{{cite web| title = Baltimore police, protesters clash; 15 officers hurt| last = Bacon | first = John| last2 = Welch | first2 = William M.| work = USA TODAY| date = April 27, 2015| accessdate = April 27, 2015| url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2015/04/27/baltimore-credible-threat/26454875/| quote = Police said more than two dozen people were arrested. The city's schools were canceled for Tuesday.}} Maryland Governor [[Larry Hogan]] declared a [[state of emergency]] and activated the [[Maryland National Guard]].{{Cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/hundreds-people-clash-police-baltimore-mall/story?id=30622868|title=Maryland Gov. Declares State of Emergency After Violent Clashes in Baltimore|first=Emily|last=Shapiro|date=April 27, 2015|accessdate=April 27, 2015|publisher=ABC News}}{{cite web|title=Governor Larry Hogan Signs Executive Order Declaring State Of Emergency, Activating National Guard|url=https://governor.maryland.gov/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/EO-4-27-2015.pdf|publisher=Government of Maryland|accessdate=April 27, 2015}} Major General [[Linda L. Singh|Linda Singh]] of the Maryland National Guard commented that there would be a "massive number" of soldiers in Maryland on the night of April 27, and that up to 5,000 soldiers could be deployed.{{cite news|last1=Laughland|first1=Oliver|last2=Lewis|first2=Paul|last3=Jacobs|first3=Ben|last4=Swaine|first4=Jon|title=Baltimore state of emergency declared as Freddie Gray protesters clash with police – live|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2015/apr/27/baltimore-police-clash-protesters-freddie-gray-live|work=The Guardian|date=April 27, 2015}} [[Maryland State Police]] activated 500 officers for duty in Baltimore, and requested an additional 5,000 state police officers from other states.{{Cite tweet |user= matthewhaybrown |number= 592853842485780481 |date=April 27, 2015 |title=Maryland State Police activating 500 officers for Baltimore; requesting up to 5,000 from neighboring states}} Business owners in the city complained that the curfew required establishments with later hours to close their doors early, thereby costing them revenue from later hours customers and hurting their employees by forcing them to work fewer hours.{{cite web|url=http://www.eater.com/2015/4/29/8513501/baltimore-curfew-restaurants-bars-servers-bartenders-freddie-gray-unrest-riots|title=How Baltimore's Mandatory Curfew Is Affecting Area Restaurants and Bars - Eater|publisher=eater.com|accessdate=May 4, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rawstory.com/2015/05/baltimores-curfew-takes-a-toll-on-city-businesses/|title=Baltimore’s curfew takes a toll on city businesses|publisher=rawstory.com|accessdate=May 4, 2015}} Some businesses complained that the curfew cost them as much as $50,000.{{cite web|url=http://touch.baltimoresun.com/#section/-1/article/p2p-83444190/|title=The Baltimore Sun|work=baltimoresun.com}} While those with night jobs were given an exemption to be allowed to travel to work, early closing hours continued to cost employees work hours. Despite criticism of curfew enforcement, Mayor Rawlings-Blake stood by the curfew, saying it was necessary to maintain control.{{cite web|url=http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2015/05/12/baltimore-mayors-curfew-authority-challenged-in-court-case-2/|title=Mayor Defends Baltimore Curfew, Says It Was Necessary To Keep Peace|work=cbslocal.com}} U.S. Attorney General Loretta Lynch requested an independent civil rights investigation into the Freddie Gray case in hopes of calming the violence in Baltimore.{{Cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/freddie-gray/bs-md-ci-gray-justice-investigation-20170119-story.html|title=Civil rights investigation into Freddie Gray's death unresolved as Trump takes office|last=Rector|first=Kevin|date=January 22, 2017|newspaper=The Baltimore Sun|access-date=February 7, 2017|work=|via=}} ====Sports actions==== The [[Baltimore Ravens]] had canceled their [[2015 NFL draft|NFL Draft]] party in response to the riots.{{cite web|title=Ravens Cancel Draft Party Event|url=http://www.baltimoreravens.com/news/article-draft/Ravens-Cancel-Draft-Party-Event/06a6bcfc-e38b-4306-87fb-5fb3ef7ff800|publisher=Baltimore Ravens|date=April 28, 2015|accessdate=April 29, 2015}}{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Michael David|title=Ravens cancel draft party amid riots in Baltimore|url=http://profootballtalk.nbcsports.com/2015/04/28/ravens-cancel-draft-party-amid-riots-in-baltimore/|publisher=NBC Sports|date=April 28, 2015|accessdate=April 29, 2015}} After consulting with [[Major League Baseball]], the [[Baltimore Orioles]] announced that their second game in a series against the [[Chicago White Sox]] would also be postponed, and that [[2015 White Sox–Orioles crowdless game|their game on April 29]] would be played in the afternoon [[behind closed doors (sport)|behind closed doors]]. This was believed to be the first behind closed doors game in Major League Baseball history (it is occasionally seen in soccer as punishment for spectator behavior).{{cite web|last=Ghiroli|first=Brittany|title=Today's White Sox-Orioles game closed to fans|url=http://m.mlb.com/news/article/121011784/white-sox-orioles-to-play-in-private-weekend-games-moved-to-tampa-bay|publisher=Major League Baseball|date=April 28, 2015|accessdate=April 29, 2015}}{{cite news|first=Steve|last=Almasy|title=Orioles game on Wednesday will have no fans|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/28/us/baltimore-orioles-game-closed/|publisher=CNN|date=April 28, 2015|accessdate=April 28, 2015}} The attendance for the game was officially recorded as zero, thus breaking the previous record (of six, set in 1882) for the lowest attendance at a Major League Baseball game.Dan Connolly, [http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/orioles/bal-baltimore-orioles-score-six-in-first-roll-to-82-win-over-chicago-white-sox-at-empty-camden-yards-20150429-story.html Orioles start fast in empty park, emerge from surreal day with 8–2 win over White Sox], ''[[Baltimore Sun]]'' (April 29, 2015). Retrieved May 1, 2015. The two cancelled games were made up as a [[doubleheader (baseball)|doubleheader]] on May 28. The team also moved its May 1–3 series against the [[Tampa Bay Rays]] from [[Oriole Park at Camden Yards|Camden Yards]] to [[Tropicana Field]], but still played as the home team (despite the Rays hosting it).{{cite web|title=Orioles-White Sox game will be played Wednesday, closed to public|url=http://espn.go.com/mlb/story/_/id/12781465/baltimore-orioles-chicago-white-sox-series-finale-played-wednesday-closed-public|publisher=ESPN|date=April 28, 2015|accessdate=April 29, 2015}} ====Gang involvement==== After Baltimore police determined there was a "credible threat" of [[gang violence]] against police officers across the country, many departments across the US heightened their security in response: for example the Los Angeles Police Department ordered their officers to ride in pairs.{{cite web| title = LAPD officers to ride in pairs after Baltimore police warn of gang threat| last = Winton | first = Richard| work = Los Angeles Times| date = April 27, 2015| accessdate = April 27, 2015| url = http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-lapd-ride-in-pairs--20150427-story.html}} Baltimore police claimed evidence to support the idea that the [[Black Guerrilla Family]], the [[Bloods]], and the [[Crips]] were "teaming up" to target police officers.{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/crime/blog/bs-md-ci-freddie-gray-gang-threat-20150427-story.html|title=Baltimore police say gangs 'teaming up' to take out officers|date=April 27, 2015|work=The Baltimore Sun|accessdate=April 28, 2015}} Later, however, leaders of both the Bloods and the Crips denied the allegations,{{cite news|last1=Porter|first1=Tom|title=Bloods and Crips gangs reject claims of kill-a-cop pact|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/baltimore-riots-bloods-crips-gangs-reject-claims-kill-cop-pact-1498790|accessdate=April 29, 2015|work=International Business Times|date=April 28, 2015}} released a video statement asking for calm and peaceful protest in the area,{{cite news|title=Gangs call for calm in Baltimore|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/baltimore-riots/bal-video-gangs-call-for-calm-in-baltimore-20150427-premiumvideo.html|accessdate=April 29, 2015|work=The Baltimore Sun|date=April 27, 2015}} and joined with police and clergy to enforce the curfew.{{cite news|last1=Berman|first1=John|last2=Castillo|first2=Mariano|title=Baltimore gangs will help enforce curfew|url=http://cnnuslive.cnn.com/Event/Baltimore_Riot/160923728|accessdate=April 29, 2015|publisher=CNN|date=April 28, 2015}} At one occasion, gang members helped to prevent a riot at the [[Security Square Mall]] by dispersing would-be rioters.{{cite web | url=http://www.wusa9.com/story/news/local/maryland/2015/04/28/gang-members-help-prevent-riot-baltimore-mall/26534797/ | title=Gang members help prevent riot at Baltimore mall | publisher=WUSA | date=April 28, 2015 | accessdate=April 29, 2015 | first=Garrett W |last=Haake}} On other occasions, rival gang members helped each other to protect black-owned businesses, black children, and reporters, diverting rioters to Korean-, Chinese-, and Arab-owned businesses instead.{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/28/us/amid-violence-factions-and-messages-converge-in-a-weary-and-unsettled-baltimore.html| title=Amid Violence, Factions and Messages Converge in a Weary and Unsettled Baltimore | work=The New York Times | date=April 27, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015 | first=Ron |last=Nixon}} On yet another occasion, the Bloods, the Crips, and the [[Nation of Islam]] were seen taking a picture together and working together to dispel violence while peacefully demonstrating.{{cite web | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/baltimore-gangs-call-for-peace-after-riots-2015-4 | title=Baltimore gangs call for peace after riots | work=Business Insider | date=April 28, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015 | author=Ryan Gorman}} ===Critical opinions=== On April 28, President [[Barack Obama]] strongly condemned the violence during a White House press conference, saying, "There's no excuse for the kind of violence that we saw yesterday. It is counterproductive. ... When individuals get crowbars and start prying open doors to loot, they're not protesting. They're not making a statement. They're stealing. When they burn down a building, they're committing arson. And they're destroying and undermining businesses and opportunities in their own communities. That robs jobs and opportunity from people in that area." Obama went on to applaud the actions of peaceful protesters who he felt were being undermined by the violence, and called upon the nation to take meaningful action to collectively solve poverty and law enforcement issues fueling what he described as "a crisis".{{cite web|url=http://ktla.com/2015/04/28/baltimore-protestors-throw-rocks-cinder-blocks-at-police-dozens-arrested/|title=President Obama Condemns Violence After More Than 200 People Are Arrested in Baltimore|publisher=KTLA|date=April 28, 2015|accessdate=April 28, 2015}} On social media and elsewhere, Mayor Rawlings-Blake and President Obama were criticized for calling the rioters "thugs" on April 28.{{cite web | url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/29/us/baltimore-riots-thug-n-word/ | title=After Baltimore riots, some leaders slam 'thug' as the new n-word | work=CNN | date=April 29, 2015 | accessdate=April 30, 2015 | author=Josh Levs}} When asked about the postponement of the [[Baltimore Orioles]] game, the Orioles' chief operating officer, [[John P. Angelos]], said: {{quote|My greater source of personal concern, outrage and sympathy ... is focused neither upon one night's property damage nor upon the acts, but is focused rather upon the past four-decade period during which an American political elite have shipped middle class and working class jobs away from Baltimore and cities and towns around the U.S. to third-world dictatorships ... plunged tens of millions of good hard working Americans into economic devastation and then followed that action around the nation by diminishing every American's civil rights protections in order to control an unfairly impoverished population living under an ever-declining standard of living and suffering at the butt end of an ever-more militarized and aggressive surveillance state. The innocent working families of all backgrounds whose lives and dreams have been cut short by excessive violence, surveillance, and other abuses of the Bill of Rights by government pay the true price, an ultimate price, and one that far exceeds the importance of any kids' game played tonight, or ever....{{cite news|last1=Mosendz|first1=Polly|title=As Riots Consume Baltimore, Orioles Postpone Baseball Game|url=http://www.newsweek.com/riots-consume-baltimore-orioles-postpone-baseball-game-325932|accessdate=April 29, 2015|work=Newsweek|date=April 27, 2015}}}} === Online reaction === The protests were originally covered on social media with the [[hashtag]] #BaltimoreRiots. However, by April 28, the more popular hashtag to cover the protests became #BaltimoreUprising. The change may have occurred in response to a decline in violent actions, or may have been the promotion of a new political narrative by social media users.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2015/04/29/when-baltimoreriots-became-baltimoreuprising/ |title='Baltimore riots' transform into 'Baltimore uprising' |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=April 29, 2015 |author= Justin Wm. Moyer |accessdate=May 21, 2015}}{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/confrontation-in-baltimore/riot-uprising-or-disturbance/ |title=Defining Baltimore: #Riot, #Uprising or #Disturbance? |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 28, 2015 |author=Damien Cave |accessdate=May 21, 2015}} === Increase in violence and decrease in policing === Baltimore recorded 43 homicides in the month of May, the second deadliest month on record and the worst since December 1971 when 44 homicides were recorded. There have also been more than 100 non-fatal shootings in May 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.wbal.com/article/115325/2/baltimores-murder-rate-ties-25-year-monthly-record|work=WBAL|title=Baltimore's Murder Total For May Climbs To 43|author=Robert Lang|date=May 31, 2015}} Police commissioner Anthony Batts blames looted drugs, stolen from 27 pharmacies and two methadone clinics, as well as street distribution and turf wars for the spike in crime.{{cite news|last=Amara|first=Kate|publisher=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|title=Police Commissioner Anthony Batts blames stolen opiates for recent violence|date=June 4, 2015|url=http://www.wbaltv.com/news/police-commissioner-anthony-batts-blames-stolen-opiates-for-recent-violence/33384202|accessdate=June 5, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Fantz|first=Ashley|publisher=[[CNN]]|title=In Baltimore, allegations of police doing less as drugs are rampant|date=June 5, 2015|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/04/us/baltimore-drugs-violence/|accessdate=June 5, 2015}} The increase in shootings has occurred along with a 50% decline in arrests since the charging of six officers in Gray's death in custody.{{cite web|url=http://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2015/05/28/baltimore-residents-fearful-amid-rash-of-homicides/|work=CBS News|title=Baltimore Gets Bloodier As Arrests Drop Post-Freddie Gray|date=May 28, 2015|quote="What is happening, there is a lot of levels of confusion in the police organization. There are people who have pain, there are people who are hurt, there are people who are frustrated, there are people who are angry," Batts said. "There are people, and they've said this to me, 'If I get out of my car and make a stop for a reasonable suspicion that leads to probable cause but I make a mistake on it, will I be arrested?' They pull up to a scene and another officer has done something that they don't know, it may be illegal, will they be arrested for it? Those are things they are asking."}} The heavy police presence in crime-ridden neighborhoods is no longer apparent with one resident stating, "Before it was over-policing. Now there's no police." One officer speaking anonymously stated, "After the protests, it seems like the citizens would appreciate a lack of police presence, and that's exactly what they're getting." Batts stated that his officers are "not holding back" despite encountering hostility in the Western District whenever they make an arrest with "30 to 50 people surrounding them at any time;" he also stated that his officers feel "confused and unsupported" in the wake of the charges. The president of the police union said his members are "afraid of going to jail for doing their jobs properly."{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2015/05/30/after-the-riots-baltimore-has-worst-murder-month-since-1996.html|work=Toronto Star|title=After the riots, Baltimore has worst murder month since 1996|author=Daniel Dale|date=May 30, 2015}} According to ''The New York Times'', looting from 27 drugstores resulted in an increase in black market access to opiates.{{cite web |title=West Baltimore's Police Presence Drops, and Murders Soar |accessdate=June 21, 2015 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/13/us/after-freddie-gray-death-west-baltimores-police-presence-drops-and-murders-soar.html?ref=todayspaper&_r=2|publisher=The New York Times|quote=[A] flood of black-market opiates stolen from 27 pharmacies during looting in April, enough for 175,000 doses now illegally available for sale.}} ==See also== {{Portal|African American|Criminal justice|Baltimore}} * [[List of riots]] * [[List of incidents of civil unrest in Baltimore]] * [[1992 Los Angeles riots]] * [[Ferguson unrest]] * [[Diversity of Tactics]] * [[List of incidents of civil unrest in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *[https://www.jacobinmag.com/2015/04/baltimore-freddie-gray-unrest-protests/ Why Baltimore Rebelled].
