described as a Saudi headed alliance to counter Iran, which engaged pro-Saudi interests in Bahrain.{{cite news|title=Bahrain: Widespread Suppression, Scant Reforms|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/01/31/bahrain-widespread-suppression-scant-reforms|accessdate=6 March 2018|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|date=31 January 2013}} ====People's Mujahedin of Iran==== [[People's Mujahedin of Iran|MEK]], a long existing rebel Iranian group has received an increasing support from Saudi Arabia.{{cite web|authors=Goulka, Jeremiah; Hansell, Lydia; Wilke, Elizabeth; Larson, Judith|url=http://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/monographs/2009/RAND_MG871.pdf|title=The Mujahedin-e Khalq in Iraq: a policy conundrum|publisher=[[RAND Corporation]]|isbn=978-0-8330-4701-4|year=2009}}{{cite news|last=Mousavian|first=Seyed Hossein|authorlink=Seyed Hossein Mousavian|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/seyed-hossein-mousavian/iran-nice-terrorism_b_11120386.html|title=From Iran to Nice, We Must Confront All Terrorism to End Terrorism|date=21 July 2016|work=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=18 August 2016}} ====Kurdish insurgents==== Saudi Arabia has allegedly provided support to the Kurdish militants within the [[Democratic Party of Iranian Kurdistan|KDPI]] and [[Kurdistan Freedom Party|PAK]] through its consulate in [[Erbil]], the capital of the [[Kurdistan Regional Government]] in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]].{{cite news |title=Iranian Kurds Return to Arms |url=https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/iranian-kurds-return-arms |accessdate=19 June 2018 |agency=Stratfor |date=29 July 2016}} ====Jaish al-Udl==== The rebel group [[Jaish ul-Adl]], active in the [[Sistan and Baluchestan Province|Sistan and Baluchestan]] region of Iran, was accused by Iranian authorities of receiving Saudi support. ====Others==== '''Israel''' The speaker of Iran's parliament, [[Ali Larijani]], stated that Saudi Arabia gave "strategic" intelligence information to Israel during the [[2006 Lebanon War]].{{cite news|title=Iran: Saudis gave Israel 'strategic' intel in 2006 Lebanon war|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/iran-saudis-gave-israel-strategic-intel-in-2006-lebanon-war/|accessdate=21 June 2017|work=The Times of Israel|date=7 June 2016}} In May 2018, Israeli defense minister Avigdor Lieberman supported greater discussion between Israel, Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states, stating "It's time for the Middle East to [...] have an axis of moderate countries," opposed to the network of Iranian allies and proxies.{{cite news|last1=O'Connor|first1=Tom|title=Saudi Arabia Should 'Come Out of the Closet' and Help Fight Iran in Syria, Israel Says|url=http://www.newsweek.com/israel-says-saudi-arabia-should-come-out-closet-help-fight-iran-syria-919500|accessdate=15 May 2018|work=[[Newsweek]]|date=10 May 2018}} As of 2018, several sources described alleged intelligence ties between Saudi Arabia and Israel as a "covert alliance", with a joint interest to counter Iran in the region.{{cite news|last1=Marcus|first1=Jonathan|title=Israel and Saudi Arabia: What's shaping the covert 'alliance'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-42094105|accessdate=4 April 2018|agency=[[BBC News]]|date=24 November 2017}} The [[The New York Times|New York Times]] remarked that such cooperation was made more difficult by controversy over Israel's attitude towards Palestinians.{{cite news|last1=Hubbard|first1=Ben|title=With Demise of Nuclear Deal, Iran's Foes See an Opportunity. Others See Risk of War.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/13/world/middleeast/iran-nuclear-mideast-conflict.html|accessdate=15 May 2018|work=The New York Times|date=13 May 2018}} '''Palestine''' In 2016, Al-Monitor mentioned an alleged meeting of the Palestinian [[President of the State of Palestine|President]] [[Mahmoud Abbas]] with the head of MEK [[Maryam Rajavi]] with Saudi backing.{{cite news|last=Karami|first=Arash|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/08/mek-palestinian-authority-mahmoud-abbas-maryam-rajavi-saudi.html|title=Were Saudis behind Abbas-MEK meeting?|date=2 August 2016|work=[[Al-Monitor]]|accessdate=18 August 2016}} '''Syria''' [[File:Flag of the Al-Nusra Front.svg|thumb|Flag of the Saudi-backed [[Al-Nusra Front]] rebel group in Syria.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/syria-crisis-turkey-and-saudi-arabia-shock-western-countries-by-supporting-antiassad-jihadists-10242747.html |title=Turkey and Saudi Arabia alarm the West by backing Islamist extremists the Americans had bombed in Syria |author=Kim Sengupta |newspaper=The Independent |date=12 May 2015}}]] {{Seealso|Al-Nusra Front|Army of Conquest|Jaysh ===Other involved parties=== ====Turkey==== {{Seealso|Turkish involvement in the Syrian Civil War|Turkish military intervention in Syria|Killing of Jamal Khashoggi}} ====Qatar==== {{See also|2017–18 Qatar diplomatic crisis}} [[Foreign relations of Saudi Arabia#Qatar|Qatar–Saudi Arabia relations]] have been strained since the beginning of the Arab Spring.{{cite news|last1=Mohyeldin|first1=Ayman|title=Qatar and Its Neighbors Have Been At Odds Since the Arab Spring|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/mideast/qatar-its-neighbors-have-been-odds-arab-spring-n768966|accessdate=7 June 2017|agency=NBC News|date=6 June 2017}} [[Qatar]] has been a focus of controversy in the Saudi-Iranian rivalry due to Saudi Arabia's longstanding concern about the country's relationship with Iran and Iranian-backed militant groups.{{cite news|last1=Wintour|first1=Patrick|title=Qatar: UAE and Saudi Arabia step up pressure in diplomatic crisis|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jun/07/qatar-fbi-says-russian-hackers-planted-fake-news-story-that-led-to-crisis-report|accessdate=7 June 2017|work=The Guardian|date=7 June 2017}} In June 2017, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Egypt, the [[Maldives]], Mauritania, Mauritius, Sudan, Senegal, Djibouti, Comoros, Jordan, the Tobruk-based Libyan government, and the [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi|Hadi]]-led Yemeni government [[2017–18 Qatar diplomatic crisis|severed diplomatic relations with Qatar]] and blocked their airspace and sea routes, in addition to Saudi Arabia blocking the only land crossing. The reasons cited were Qatar's relations with Iran, [[Al-Jazeera]]'s coverage of other GCC states and Egypt, and Qatar's alleged [[Qatar and state-sponsored terrorism|support of Islamist groups]].{{cite news|last1=Gambrell|first1=Jon|title=Arab nations cut ties with Qatar in new Mideast crisis|url=https://apnews.com/8257ce650e224188a1884e34eabb5e90/4-Arab-nations-cut-diplomatic-ties-to-Qatar-as-rift-deepens|accessdate=6 June 2017|agency=Associated Press|date=6 June 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Browning|first1=Noah|title=Yemen cuts diplomatic ties with Qatar: state news agency|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-yemen-idUSKBN18W0RS|accessdate=6 July 2017|agency=Reuters|date=5 June 2017}} Qatar was also expelled from the anti-[[Houthi]] coalition.{{cite news|title=Qatar row: Saudi and Egypt among countries to cut Doha links|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-40155829|accessdate=12 July 2017|agency=BBC News|date=5 June 2017}} Qatar's defense minister Khalid bin Mohammed Al Attiyah called the blockade akin to a bloodless declaration of war, and Qatar's finance minister [[Ali Sharif Al Emadi]] stated that Qatar was rich enough to withstand the blockade.{{cite news|last1=Khatri|first1=Shabina S.|title=Defense minister: Blockade of Qatar a 'declaration of war'|url=https://dohanews.co/defense-minister-blockade-of-qatar-a-declaration-of-war/|accessdate=12 July 2017|agency=Doha News|date=1 July 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Alkhalisi|first1=Zahraa|title=Qatar: 'We can defend our currency and the economy'|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/06/22/news/economy/qatar-economy-finance-minister/index.html|accessdate=12 July 2017|agency=CNN|date=22 June 2017}} The bloc sought a guarantee that Qatar will in the future align in all matters with other Gulf states, discuss all of its decisions with them, and provide regular reports on its activity (monthly for the first year, quarterly for the second, and annually for the following ten years). They also demanded the deportation of all political refugees who live in Qatar to their countries of origin, freezing their assets, providing any desired information about their residency, movements, and finances, and revoking their Qatari citizenship if naturalized. They also demanded that Qatar be forbidden from granting citizenship to any additional fugitives.{{cite news|last1=Fahim|first1=Kareem|title=Demands by Saudi-led Arab states for Qatar include shuttering Al Jazeera|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/saudi-led-arab-states-submit-demands-to-qatar-including-shuttering-of-al-jazeera/2017/06/23/d9d2711a-580e-11e7-9e18-968f6ad1e1d3_story.html|accessdate=23 June 2017|work=The Washington Post|date=23 June 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Erickson|first1=Amanda|title=Why Saudi Arabia hates Al Jazeera so much|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/06/23/why-saudi-arabia-hates-al-jazeera-so-much/|accessdate=23 June 2017|work=The Washington Post|date=23 June 2017}} Upon Qatar's rejection of these demands, the countries involved announced that the blockade would remain in place until Qatar changed its policies.{{cite news|title=Saudi-led group: Qatar not serious about demands|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/07/saudi-led-group-qatar-demands-170705144209453.html|accessdate=20 July 2017|agency=Al Jazeera|date=6 July 2017}}{{cite news|title=Saudi-led group vows 'appropriate' measures|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/07/saudi-led-group-vows-measures-qatar-170706222931408.html|accessdate=20 July 2017|agency=Al Jazeera|date=7 July 2017}} On 24 August 2017, Qatar announced that they would restore full diplomatic relations with Iran.{{cite news|title=Qatar To Reinstate Ambassador To Iran Amid Gulf Crisis|url=http://www.ndtv.com/world-news/qatar-to-reinstate-ambassador-to-iran-amid-gulf-crisis-1741557|date=24 August 2017}} ====Russia==== Russia has been aligned with Iran and Syria for years. It [[Russian military intervention in the Syrian Civil War|intervened in Syria]] to provide support for the Assad government and to target rebel groups, working together with Iran and using Iranian air bases to stage air strikes.{{cite news|title=Syrian conflict: Russian bombers use Iran bases for air strikes|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-37093854|accessdate=6 October 2016|agency=BBC News|date=16 August 2016}} It also joined Iran, Iraq, and Syria in forming a [[Russia–Syria–Iran–Iraq coalition|joint intelligence-sharing coalition]] as part of the fight against [[ISIL]].{{cite news|last1=Mullen|first1=Jethro|last2=Basil|first2=Yousuf|title=Iraq agrees to share intelligence with Russia, Iran and Syria|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2015/09/27/middleeast/iraq-russia-iran-syria-intelligence-deal/|accessdate=9 March 2018|agency=CNN|date=28 September 2015}} The alliance coincided with the [[Combined Joint Task Force – Operation Inherent Resolve|US-led coalition]] created a year earlier to fight ISIL. The competing military actions were seen as part of a larger proxy conflict between the United States and Russia.{{cite news|last1=Barnard|first1=Anne|last2=Shoumali|first2=Karam|title=U.S. Weaponry Is Turning Syria Into a Proxy War With Russia|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/13/world/middleeast/syria-russia-airstrikes.html?_r=0|accessdate=9 March 2018|work=The New York Times|date=12 October 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Pengelly|first1=Martin|title=John McCain says US is engaged in proxy war with Russia in Syria|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/oct/04/john-mccain-russia-us-proxy-war-syria-obama-putin|accessdate=9 March 2018|work=The Guardian|date=4 October 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Tilghman|first1=Andrew|last2=Pawlyk|first2=Oriana|title=U.S. vs. Russia: What a war would look like between the world's most fearsome militaries|url=https://www.militarytimes.com/news/your-military/2015/10/04/u-s-vs-russia-what-a-war-would-look-like-between-the-world-s-most-fearsome-militaries/|accessdate=9 March 2018|work=Military Times|date=4 October 2015}} ====China==== In a conversation with King Salman in March 2018, Chinese [[President of the People's Republic of China|President]] [[Xi Jinping]] expressed interest in increased strategic cooperation with Saudi Arabia. Although it has traditionally stayed out of the conflict despite relying on the region for oil, China has recently played both sides, and has had ties with Tehran for years. Although it has warm relations with the Assad government, China has not involved itself in the Syrian Civil War, instead supporting the Russian-led peace process and investing in Syria's reconstruction.{{cite news |last1=O'Connor |first1=Tom |title=China May Be the Biggest Winner of All If Assad Takes Over Syria |url=https://www.newsweek.com/china-did-not-fight-syria-won-war-754644 |accessdate=21 August 2018 |date=19 January 2018}} China's increased involvement in the region has come at a time when Xi Jinping has sought to expand China's global influence.{{cite news|last1=Buckley|first1=Chris|title=Xi Jinping Thought Explained: A New Ideology for a New Era|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/26/world/asia/xi-jinping-thought-explained-a-new-ideology-for-a-new-era.html|accessdate=16 March 2018|work=The New York Times|date=26 February 2018}} ==Involvement in regional conflicts== ====Syrian Civil War==== {{main|Saudi Arabian involvement in the Syrian Civil War|Iranian involvement in the Syrian Civil War}} [[Syria]] has been a major theater in the proxy conflict throughout its ongoing [[Syrian Civil War|civil war]], which began in 2011. Iran and the GCC states have provided varying degrees of military and financial support to opposing sides, with Iran backing the government and Saudi Arabia supporting rebel militants. [[File:Defence ministers of the three allied powers in the Syrian Civil War.jpg|thumbnail|left|200px|The defense ministers of Russia, Iran, and Syria in [[Tehran]] on 10 June 2016]] Syria is an important part of Iran's sphere of influence, and the [[Council of Ministers (Syria)|government]] under [[Bashar al-Assad]] has long been a major ally. During the early stages of the Arab Spring, [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Supreme Leader]] [[Ali Khamenei|Khamenei]] initially expressed support for the revolutions in [[Tunisian Revolution|Tunisia]] and [[Egyptian revolution of 2011|Egypt]], characterizing them as an "Islamic awakening" akin to its own revolution in 1979. When [[Civil uprising phase of the Syrian Civil War|protests]] broke out in Syria, Iran changed its position and condemned them, comparing the uprising to its own [[2009 Iranian presidential election protests|presidential election protests]] in 2009 and accusing the United States and Israel of being behind the unrest.{{cite news|last1=Khalaji|first1=Mehdi|title=Iran's Policy Confusion about Bahrain|url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/irans-policy-confusion-about-bahrain|accessdate=7 October 2016|publisher=[[The Washington Institute for Near East Policy]]|date=27 June 2011}} The war threatens Iran's position, and Saudi Arabia and its allies have sided with Sunni rebels in part to weaken Iran. For years Iranian forces have been involved on the ground, with soldiers in Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps facing heavy casualties.{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Henry|title=Mapping the Deaths of Iranian Officers Across Syria|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-syria-crisis-iran-idUSBREA1K09U20140221|accessdate=6 October 2016|work=Foreign Policy|date=30 October 2015}} In 2014, with no end in sight to the conflict, Iran increased its ground support for the [[Syrian Army]], providing elite forces, intelligence gathering, and training. Iran also backs pro-Assad Hezbollah fighters.{{cite news|last1=Saul|first1=Jonathan|last2=Hafezi|first2=Parisa|title=Iran boosts military support in Syria to bolster Assad|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-syria-crisis-iran-idUSBREA1K09U20140221|accessdate=6 October 2016|agency=Reuters|date=21 February 2014}} Although Iran and Saudi Arabia agreed in 2015 to participate in peace talks in Vienna in participation with [[United States Secretary of State]] [[John Kerry]] and Russian [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Foreign Minister]] [[Sergey Lavrov]], the talks ultimately failed.{{cite news|last1=Sanger|first1=David E.|last2=Kirkpatrick|first2=David D.|last3=Sengupta|first3=Somini|title=Rancor Between Saudi Arabia and Iran Threatens Talks on Syria|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/30/world/middleeast/syria-saudi-arabia-iran-peace-talks.html|accessdate=6 October 2016|work=The New York Times|date=29 October 2015}} Saudi Arabia countered Russia's intervention in Syria by increasing its support for the rebels and supplying American-made anti-tank [[BGM-71 TOW|TOW missiles]], a move which slowed initial progress made by Russian and Syrian forces.{{cite news|last1=Bassam|first1=Laila|last2=Perry|first2=Tom|title=Saudi support to rebels slows Assad attacks: pro-Damascus sources|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-syria-idUSKCN0SV23O20151106|accessdate=6 October 2016|agency=Reuters|date=6 November 2015}} ====Yemeni Civil War==== {{main|Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen}} [[File:Air strike in Sana'a 11-5-2015.jpg|thumb|An airstrike in [[Sana'a]] by a Saudi-led coalition on 11 May 2015]] Yemen has been called one of the major fronts in the conflict as a result of the [[Yemeni Revolution|revolution]] and subsequent [[Yemeni Civil War (2015–present)|civil war]].{{cite news|last1=Reardon|first1=Martin|title=Saudi Arabia, Iran and the 'Great Game' in Yemen|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2014/09/saudi-arabia-iran-great-game-ye-201492984846324440.html|accessdate=20 September 2016|agency=Al Jazeera|date=26 March 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Malsin|first1=Jared|title=Yemen Is the Latest Victim of the Increase in Iran-Saudi Arabia Tension|url=http://time.com/4174837/yemen-analysis/|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=Time|issue=11 January 2016}} Yemen had for years been within the Saudi sphere of influence. The decade-long [[Houthi insurgency in Yemen]] stoked tensions with Iran, with accusations of covert support for the rebels. A 2015 UN report alleged that Iran provided the [[Houthi]] rebels with money, training, and arms shipments beginning in 2009.{{cite news|last1=Landry|first1=Carole|title=Iran arming Yemen's Huthi rebels since 2009: UN report|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/iran-arming-yemens-huthi-rebels-since-2009-un-202936346.html|accessdate=20 September 2016|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=[[Yahoo! News|Yahoo News]]|date=30 April 2015}} However, the degree of support has been subject to debate, and accusations of greater involvement have been denied by Iran.{{cite news|last1=Schmitt|first1=Eric|last2=Worth|first2=Robert F.|title=With Arms for Yemen Rebels, Iran Seeks Wider Mideast Role|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/15/world/middleeast/aiding-yemen-rebels-iran-seeks-wider-mideast-role.html|accessdate=20 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=15 March 2012}}{{cite news|last1=Bayoumy|first1=Yara|last2=Ghobari|first2=Mohammed|title=Iranian support seen crucial for Yemen's Houthis|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-houthis-iran-insight-idUSKBN0JT17A20141215|accessdate=20 September 2016|agency=Reuters|date=15 December 2014}} The [[Houthi takeover in Yemen|2014–2015 coup d'état]] was viewed by Saudi leadership as an immediate threat, and as an opportunity for Iran to gain a foothold in the region. In March 2015, a Saudi-led coalition of Arab states, including all GCC members except [[Oman]], [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|intervened]] and launched airstrikes and a ground offensive in the country, declaring the entire [[Saada Governorate]] a military target and imposing a naval blockade.{{cite news|last1=Miles|first1=Tom|title=Saudi-led strikes in Yemen break international law: U.N. coordinator|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-yemen-security-saudi-un-idUSKBN0NU0PN20150509|accessdate=20 September 2016|agency=Reuters|date=9 May 2015}} The United States intervened in October 2016 after missiles were fired at a US warship, which was in place to protect oil shipments along the sea lane passing through the [[Bab-el-Mandeb|Mandeb Strait]]. The US blamed the rebels and responded by targeting radar sites with missile strikes along the [[Red Sea]] coast. In response, rebels called the strikes evidence of American support for the Saudi campaign.{{cite news|last1=Mazzetti|first1=Mark|last2=Hubbard|first2=Ben|last3=Rosenberg|first3=Matthew|title=Yemen Sees U.S. Strikes as Evidence of Hidden Hand Behind Saudi Air War|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/14/world/middleeast/yemen-united-states-missiles-radar.html|accessdate=14 October 2016|work=The New York Times|date=13 October 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Gaouette|first1=Nicole|title=US in Yemen: If you threaten us, we'll respond|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/13/politics/yemen-us-strike-iran-houthis/|accessdate=14 October 2016|agency=CNN|date=13 October 2016}} ====Iraqi Civil War==== {{main|Iranian intervention in Iraq (2014–present)}} While the majority of Muslims in Iraq are Shia, the country has been ruled for decades by Sunni-dominated governments under the [[Ottoman Empire]], the British-installed [[Kingdom of Iraq|Hashemites]], and the [[Ba'athist Iraq|Ba'athists]]. Under the rule of Saddam Hussein, Iraq was hostile to both Iran and Saudi Arabia and acted as a counterbalancing regional power. The [[2003 invasion of Iraq|American-led invasion]] in 2003 caused a power vacuum in the region. With the antagonistic Ba'athist regime removed, Iran sought a more friendly Shia-dominated government and supported sympathetic rebel factions as part of an effort to undermine the coalition, which Iran feared would install a government hostile to its interests.{{cite news|last1=Fisher|first1=Max|title=How the Iranian-Saudi Proxy Struggle Tore Apart the Middle East|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/20/world/middleeast/iran-saudi-proxy-war.html|accessdate=2 November 2017|work=The New York Times|date=19 November 2016}} Saudi Arabia remained more passive during the occupation of Iraq, taking caution to preserve its relations with the United States by avoiding any direct support of Sunni insurgent groups. Riyadh supported the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush administration]]'s commitment to stay in the country, as it limited Iran's influence.{{cite journal|last1=Gause III|first1=F. Gregory|title=Saudi Arabia: Iraq, Iran, the Regional Power Balance, and the Sectarian Question|journal=Strategic Insights|date=March 2007|volume=6|issue=2|url=http://calhoun.nps.edu/bitstream/handle/10945/11181/gauseMar07.pdf|accessdate=20 December 2016}} The edicts issued in May 2003 by [[Coalition Provisional Authority]] Administrator [[Paul Bremer]] to exclude members of the [[Ba'ath Party (Iraqi-dominated faction)|Ba'ath Party]] from the new Iraqi government and to disband the Iraqi Army undermined the occupation effort. The orders empowered various insurgent factions and weakened the new government's functional capabilities, leaving Iraq vulnerable to future instability.{{cite journal|last1=Pfiffner|first1=James P.|title=US Blunders in Iraq: De-Baathification and Disbanding the Army|journal=Intelligence and National Security|date=February 2010|volume=25|issue=1|url=http://pfiffner.gmu.edu/files/pdfs/Articles/CPA%20Orders,%20Iraq%20PDF.pdf|accessdate=20 December 2016|doi=10.1080/02684521003588120}} Following the United States [[Withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq|withdrawal from Iraq]] in December 2011, the country drifted further into Iran's sphere of influence. The instability that resulted from the [[Iraqi Civil War (2014–2017)|Iraqi Civil War]] and the rise of ISIL threatened the existence of the Iraqi regime and led to an [[Iranian intervention in Iraq (2014–present)|Iranian intervention]] in 2014. Iran mobilized Shia militia groups to halt and ultimately push back the advancing Sunni insurgency{{cite news|last1=Milani|first1=Mohsen|title=Tehran Doubles Down|url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/iran/2014-06-22/tehran-doubles-down|accessdate=5 December 2016|work=Foreign Affairs|date=22 June 2014}}, though the resurgence of ISIL in Iraq remains more than a possibility.{{Cite web|url=https://dailytimes.com.pk/248934/isis-resurgence-more-than-likely-in-iraq|title=ISIS resurgence more than likely in Iraq|last=Foizee|first=Bahauddin|date=June 5, 2018|website=Daily Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 1, 2018}} The Iraqi government remains particularly influenced by Iran, and consults with it on most matters.{{cite news|last1=Foizee|first1=Bahauddin|title=Iranian Influence Gives Saudi Arabia Heartburn|url=https://intpolicydigest.org/2016/12/11/iranian-influence-gives-saudi-arabia-heartburn/|accessdate=20 December 2016|work=International Policy Digest|date=11 December 2016}} As of 2018 Iran has become Iraq's top trading partner, with an annual turnover of approximately $12 billion [[United States dollar|USD]] compared to the $6 billion USD in trade between Iraq and Saudi Arabia. In addition to fostering economic ties, Tehran furthered its influence by aiding the Iraqi government [[2017 Iraqi–Kurdish conflict|in its fight]] against the [[Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum, 2017|push for independence]] in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]].{{cite news|last1=Georgy|first1=Michael|last2=Aboulenein|first2=Ahmed|last3=Rasheed|first3=Ahmed|title=In symbolic victory, Iran conquers Iraq's dates market|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-iran-dates/in-symbolic-victory-iran-conquers-iraqs-dates-market-idUSKBN1GX1I1|agency=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=22 March 2018|date=21 March 2018}} Saudi Arabia has responded by strengthening its ties to the [[Kurdistan Regional Government]], seeing it as a barrier to the expansion of Iranian influence in the region, while also adopting a [[soft power]] approach to improve relations with the Iraqi government.{{cite web|agency=[[Stratfor]]|url=https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/gulf-arab-countries-and-kurdish-referendum|last=Ibish|first=Hussein|title=The Gulf Arab Countries and the Kurdish Referendum|date=4 October 2017}}{{cite news|title=Saudi Arabia's use of soft power in Iraq is making Iran nervous|url=https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21738405-kingdom-eyeing-southern-iraq-which-iran-considers-its-backyard-saudi|accessdate=9 March 2018|work=[[The Economist]]|date=8 March 2018}} [[Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri]], former Ba'athist official and leader of the [[Naqshbandi Army]] insurgent group, has repeatedly praised Saudi efforts to constrain Iranian clout in Iraq.{{cite news|agency=Reuters|title=Former Saddam aide seeks to reshape Iraq's Sunni insurgency|accessdate=2 August 2018|date=10 April 2016|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-douri/former-saddam-aide-seeks-to-reshape-iraqs-sunni-insurgency-idUSKCN0X70L6}}{{cite news|work=[[Rudaw]]|title=Saddam’s ‘king of clubs’ reappears on Baath anniversary|date=8 April 2018|url=http://www.rudaw.net/english/middleeast/iraq/080420181}} Recently, Saudi Arabia has developed a close relationship with Shia cleric [[Muqtada al-Sadr]], the leader of the [[Sadrist Movement]] and the [[Peace Companies]] militia.{{cite news|work=The Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2017/08/10/why-a-controversial-iraqi-shiite-cleric-visited-saudi-arabia/?noredirect=on|last=Haddad|first=Fanar|title=Why a controversial Iraqi Shiite cleric visited Saudi Arabia|date=August 10, 2017}} ====Bahraini uprising==== {{main|Saudi-led intervention in Bahrain}} [[File:March of 9 march 7.JPG|thumb|[[Aftermath of the Bahraini uprising (January–August 2012)|Bahraini anti-government protests]] in 2012]] Saudi Arabia and Iran have sought to extend their influence in Bahrain for decades. While the majority of Muslims in Bahrain are Shia, the country is ruled by the Sunni [[House of Khalifa|Al Khalifa]] family. Iran claimed sovereignty over Bahrain until 1970, when Shah [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]] abandoned claims after negotiations with the United Kingdom.{{cite journal|last=Alvandi|first=Roham|title=Muhammad Reza Pahlavi and the Bahrain Question, 1968–1970|journal=British Journal of Middle Eastern Studies|year=2010|volume=32|issue=2|pages=159–177|doi=10.1080/13530191003794723}} The Iranian Revolution led to resumed interest in Bahraini affairs. In 1981, the front organization [[Islamic Front for the Liberation of Bahrain]] led a [[1981 Bahraini coup d'état attempt|failed coup attempt]] to install a Shia theocratic regime led by [[Hadi al-Modarresi]]. Since then, the government has accused Iran of supporting terrorist plots within its borders.{{cite news|last1=Hashem|first1=Ali|title=Will Iran, Saudi Arabia patch things up?|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/01/iran-saudi-arabia-proxy-war-diplomatic-relations-cut.html|accessdate=13 July 2016|work=Al-Monitor|date=19 January 2016}} Sunni states have long feared that Iran might stir up unrest among regional Shia minority populations, especially in Bahrain. The Al Khalifa regime's stability depends heavily on Saudi support. The island is connected to Saudi Arabia by the 25 kilometer [[King Fahd Causeway]], and its proximity to Saudi Arabia's oil-rich, majority Shia [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]] is viewed by Riyadh as a security concern. Any political gains by the Shia in Bahrain are seen by the Saudis as gains for Iran.{{cite news|last1=Mabon|first1=Simon|title=After years of proxy war, Saudi Arabia and Iran are finally squaring up in the open|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/after-years-of-proxy-war-saudi-arabia-and-iran-are-finally-squaring-up-in-the-open-a6797001.html|accessdate=13 July 2016|work=The Independent|date=5 January 2016}} In response to the Arab Spring in 2011, the GCC regimes sought to maintain their legitimacy through social reform, economic handouts, and violent repression. Member states also distributed a share of their combined oil wealth to Bahrain and Oman to maintain stability.{{cite journal|last1=Friedman|first1=Brandon|title=Battle for Bahrain: What One Uprising Meant for the Gulf States and Iran|journal=World Affairs|date=2012|issue=March/April 2012|url=http://www.worldaffairsjournal.org/article/battle-bahrain-what-one-uprising-meant-gulf-states-and-iran|accessdate=15 July 2016}} Saudi-led GCC forces quickly [[Peninsula Shield Force#Role in Bahraini uprising|intervened]] in support of the Al Khalifa regime to put down the [[Bahraini protests of 2011|anti-government uprising]] in Bahrain. The Bahraini government publicly blamed Iran for the protests, but an [[Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry|independent commission]] established by [[Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa|King Hamad]] rejected the claim, instead highlighting human rights abuses committed in the crackdown.{{cite news|title=Bahrain protesters join anti-government march in Manama|date=9 March 2012|publisher=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-17309839|accessdate=19 June 2017}} The protests, along with the Iran nuclear deal, strained Bahrain's relationship with the United States. Bahrain has sought closer ties with Russia as a result, but this has been limited due to Saudi Arabia's alliance with the US.{{cite news|last1=Cafiero|first1=Giorgio|title=Can Bahrain count on Moscow to fill Washington’s shoes?|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2016/07/bahrain-russia-replace-washington-influence-iran.html|accessdate=13 July 2016|work=Al-Monitor|date=8 July 2016}} Following the onset of the [[Arab Winter]], Bahrain accused Iran of orchestrating several domestic incidents as part of a campaign to destabilize the country. Tehran denied all allegations and accused the government of Bahrain of blaming its own internal problems on Iran after every incident.{{cite news|title=Bahrain says pipeline explosion 'terrorist sabotage' linked to Iran|url=http://www.dw.com/en/bahrain-says-pipeline-explosion-terrorist-sabotage-linked-to-iran/a-41347255|accessdate=21 November 2017|agency=[[Deutsche Welle]]|date=12 November 2017}} In August 2015, authorities in Bahrain arrested five suspects over a bombing in [[Sitra]]. Officials linked the attacks to the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|Revolutionary Guard]] and [[Hezbollah]], although Iran denied any involvement.{{cite journal|last=Hou|first=Qiang|title=Bahrain arrests 5 suspects over late July blast, claims Iran's role discovered|date=13 August 2015|accessdate=19 June 2017|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2015-08/13/c_134513434.htm}} In January 2016, Bahrain joined Saudi Arabia in cutting diplomatic ties with Tehran following [[2016 attack on the Saudi diplomatic missions in Iran|the attacks]] on Saudi diplomatic missions in Iran.{{cite news|last1=Shoichet|first1=Catherine E.|last2=Castillo|first2=Mariano|title=Saudi Arabia-Iran row spreads to other nations|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/04/middleeast/saudi-arabia-iran-severing-ties-whats-next/|accessdate=13 July 2016|agency=CNN|date=4 January 2016}} In November 2017, Bahrain called an explosion on its main oil pipeline "terrorist sabotage" linked to Iran, drawing a rebuke from Tehran. Saudi Arabia also referred to the incident as an "attack on the pipeline". ====Lebanese arena==== {{See also|2017 Lebanon–Saudi Arabia dispute}} In 2008, Saudi Arabia proposed creating an Arab force backed by US and NATO air and sea power to intervene in Lebanon and destroy Iranian-backed Hezbollah, according to a US diplomatic cable released by [[WikiLeaks]]. According to the cable Saudi argued that a Hezbollah victory against the [[Fouad Siniora|Siniora]] government "combined with Iranian actions in Iraq and on the Palestinian front would be a disaster for the US and the entire region".{{cite news|last1=MacAskill|first1=Ewen|title=WikiLeaks cables: Saudis proposed Arab force to invade Lebanon|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/07/wikileaks-saudi-arab-invasion-lebanon|accessdate=21 June 2017|work=The Guardian|date=7 December 2010}}{{cite web|title=Lebanon: SAG FM says UN peace keeping force needed now|url=https://wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/08RIYADH768_a.html|publisher=WikiLeaks|accessdate=21 June 2017|date=14 May 2008}} In February 2016 Saudi Arabia and the UAE banned their citizens from visiting [[Lebanon]] and suspended [[military aid]] due to possible [[Hezbollah|Iranian influence]] and Lebanon's refusal to condemn the [[2016 attack on the Saudi diplomatic missions in Iran|attack on Saudi embassy]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/saudi-arabia-and-uae-tell-citizens-not-go-lebanon-1263867364|title=Saudi Arabia and UAE tell citizens to avoid Lebanon|publisher=Middle East Eye|date=23 February 2016|accessdate=24 February 2016}}{{cite news|title=Saudi and UAE ban citizens from travelling to Lebanon|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/02/saudi-uae-ban-citizens-travelling-lebanon-160223154000581.html|accessdate=19 July 2017|agency=Al Jazeera|date=23 February 2016}} Lebanese [[List of Prime Ministers of Lebanon|Prime Minister]] [[Saad Hariri]] resigned on 4 November 2017. The situation was seen as a power play by Saudi Arabia to increase its influence in Lebanon and counterbalance Iran's victories in Iraq and Syria.{{cite news|last1=Perry|first1=Tom|last2=Bassam|first2=Laila|title=Saudi reopens Lebanon front in struggle with Iran|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-lebanon-politics-hariri-analysis/saudi-reopens-lebanon-front-in-struggle-with-iran-idUSKBN1D72BA|accessdate=8 November 2017|agency=Reuters|date=7 November 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Alsaafin|first1=Linah|last2=Najjar|first2=Farah|title=Is Lebanon caught in a Saudi-Iran regional power play?|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/11/lebanon-caught-saudi-iran-regional-power-play-171107075704436.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|agency=Al Jazeera|date=8 November 2017}} In a televised speech from Saudi Arabia, Hariri criticized Hezbollah and blamed Iran for causing "disorder and destruction" in Lebanon. Hezbollah leader [[Hassan Nasrallah]] responded by accusing Hariri of resigning on Riyadh's orders.{{cite news|last1=Younes|first1=Ali|last2=Mandhai|first2=Shafik|title=Saudi-Iran power struggle to fill void in Lebanon|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/11/saudi-iran-power-struggle-fill-void-lebanon-171108093252094.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|agency=Al Jazeera|date=8 November 2017}} ====War in Afghanistan==== The rivalry has contributed to the [[War in Afghanistan (1978–present)|ongoing instability]] in [[Afghanistan]]. Afghanistan shares historical ties with Iran, and is strategically important to Saudi Arabia. After the Cold War, Saudi policy shifted from fighting the spread of communism to containing Iranian influence in South and Central Asia. Saudi Arabia was one of three countries to officially recognize the Sunni [[Taliban]] government in 1996, along with its allies Pakistan and the United Arab Emirates. During the [[Afghan Civil War (1996–2001)|Afghan Civil War]], Iran and Saudi Arabia supported opposing militant factions. Iran assisted the Shia [[Hizb-i-Wahdat]], while Saudi Arabia provided financial support to the Wahhabist [[Islamic Dawah Organisation of Afghanistan|Ittihad-i Islami]].{{cite web|first=John|last=Sifton|date=6 July 2005|accessdate=11 April 2018|title=Blood-Stained Hands: Past Atrocities in Kabul and Afghanistan's Legacy of Impunity|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|url=https://www.hrw.org/en/reports/2005/07/06/blood-stained-hands}} In 2001, the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–2014)|invasion of Afghanistan]] and the removal of the Taliban in the wake of the [[September 11 attacks]] benefited Iran, which had previously been on the brink of war with the group. The regime change removed Iran's primary threat along its eastern borders, and the removal of Saddam Hussein two years later further bolstered its position, allowing it to refocus its efforts on other areas, especially Syria and Yemen.{{cite news|last1=Quince|first1=Annabelle|title=Iran and Saudi Arabia: Divisions, proxy wars and chaos in the Middle East|url=http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/rearvision/iran-saudi-arabia-sectarian-divisions-proxy-wars-chaos/7152358|accessdate=21 September 2016|agency=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|publisher=Radio National|date=9 February 2016}} In the ensuing years, Iran sought to expand its influence over Afghanistan. It provided limited support to the Taliban as a potential means of increasing leverage with the Afghan central government and creating a deterrent to conflict with the United States, although the support waned amid growing backlash in Afghanistan against perceived Iranian interference.{{cite web|authors=Nader, Alireza; Scotten, Ali G.; Rahmani, Ahmad Idrees; Stewart, Robert; Mahnad, Leila|url=https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/research_reports/RR600/RR616/RAND_RR616.pdf|title=Iran's Influence in Afghanistan: Implications for the U.S. Drawdown|publisher=RAND Corporation|isbn=978-0-8330-8592-4|year=2014}} Iran has also sought to expand soft influence by building pro-Iranian schools, mosques, and media centers, and by maintaining close ties with Afghanistan's [[Tajiks|Tajik]] and [[Hazaras|Hazara]] populations. ====Pakistani sectarian violence==== Since 1989 [[Pakistan]] has been dealing with [[Sectarian violence in Pakistan|sectarian conflict]]. The population is predominantly Sunni and has about 10-15% of Shia adherents.{{cite web|title=South Asia: Pakistan|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pk.html|website=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=Central Intelligence Agency|accessdate=28 June 2017}} Pakistan is economically dependent on Saudi Arabia and a key strategic ally. The country's economic stability relies heavily on foreign workers who send money home. The largest amount comes from the 1.5 million Pakistanis working in Saudi Arabia who sent home about $5.5 billion USD in remittances in 2017.{{cite news|last1=Shah|first1=Saeed|last2=Talley|first2=Ian|title=Saudi Arabia Stymies U.S. Over Pakistan Terror List|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/pakistan-avoids-inclusion-on-international-terror-financing-watch-list-1519257040|accessdate=22 February 2018|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=21 February 2018}} Saudi Arabia has invested in the country's nuclear weapons projects, and believes it could use Pakistan to quickly obtain nuclear weapons at will.{{cite news|last1=Urban|first1=Mark|title=Saudi nuclear weapons 'on order' from Pakistan|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-24823846|accessdate=15 November 2017|agency=BBC News|date=6 November 2013}} Riyadh also sees the province of [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]] as a potential means of stirring ethnic unrest in neighboring Iran.{{cite news|last1=Dorsey|first1=James|title=The Middle East Will Only Get Worse|url=https://www.fairobserver.com/region/middle_east_north_africa/saad-hariri-saudi-arabia-iran-hezbollah-israel-war-world-news-43400/|accessdate=15 November 2017|agency=Fair Observer|date=8 November 2017}} In 2015, Pakistan declared its neutrality in the conflict in Yemen after Saudi solicitations for military support. It ultimately provided some degree of covert support, joining [[Somalia]] in sending proxy forces to aid the Saudi-led campaign against Houthi rebels. In 2016, Saudi Arabia sought closer ties with Pakistan as part of its "look east" policy of expanding its reach to East and South Asia.{{cite news|last1=Shams|first1=Shamil|title=Examining Saudi-Pakistani ties in changing geopolitics|url=http://www.dw.com/en/examining-saudi-pakistani-ties-in-changing-geopolitics/a-19512946|accessdate=5 October 2016|publisher=Deutsche Welle|date=30 August 2016}} In February 2018, Saudi Arabia, acting on behalf of the GCC, joined China and Turkey in opposing a US-led initiative to place Pakistan on an international terror-financing watch list through the [[Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering|Financial Action Task Force]]. This move came days after Pakistan pledged to send 1,000 troops to the Gulf kingdoms for what it described as an advisory mission. Iran has been accused of influencing young Pakistani Shias to act as proxies to further Iranian interests in Pakistan. The Iranian government has been suspected of militarizing Shia loyalists amongst Pakistan's local population and promoting sectarian sentiments to further achieve its goals.{{cite web|url=http://pakistan.asia-news.com/en_GB/articles/cnmi_pf/features/2018/02/16/feature-01|title=Iran manipulates Pakistani Shia to satisfy 'nefarious' geopolitical agenda|first=Pakistan|last=Forward|publisher=}} Many Pakistani Shias have also been suspected of traveling to parts of the Middle East including Syria and Lebanon to fight on behalf of the Iranian government.{{cite web|url=http://pakistan.asia-news.com/en_GB/articles/cnmi_pf/features/2017/09/26/feature-01|title=Pakistani pilgrims are being recruited into Iran's mercenary groups|first=Pakistan|last=Forward|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1007694/iran-recruits-pakistani-shias-for-combat-in-syria/|title=Iran recruits Pakistani Shias for combat in Syria - The Express Tribune|date=11 December 2015|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/tribune-supplements/world-tribune/2017/09/17/iran-recruits-afghan-pakistani-shias-fight-syria/|title=Iran recruits Afghan and Pakistani Shias to fight in Syria - Dhaka Tribune|website=www.dhakatribune.com}} ==Nuclear programs of Iran and Saudi Arabia== {{main|Nuclear program of Saudi Arabia|Iran and weapons of mass destruction}} Although both Iran and Saudi Arabia signed the [[Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons]] in 1970 and 1988 respectively, a potential nuclear arms race has been a concern for years. Both governments claim that their programs are for peaceful purposes, but foreign governments and organizations have accused both of taking steps to obtain nuclear weapons capabilities. Iran's ongoing [[Nuclear program of Iran|nuclear program]] began in the 1950s under the Shah in cooperation with the United States as part of the [[Atoms for Peace]] program. The cooperation continued until the Iranian Revolution in 1979.{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/chi-061209atoms-day1-story,0,2034260.htmlstory|title=An atomic threat made in America|last=Roe|first=Sam|date=28 January 2007|work=Chicago Tribune |accessdate=22 June 2017}} [[Sanctions on Iran|Sanctions]] have been in place since then, and were expanded in 2006 with the passage of United Nation Security Council [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1737|Resolution 1737]] and [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1696|Resolution 1696]] in response to Iran's uranium enrichment program. Saudi Arabia has considered several options in response to the Iranian program: acquiring its own [[Nuclear program of Saudi Arabia|nuclear capability]] as a deterrent, entering into an alliance with an existing nuclear power, or pursuing a regional [[nuclear-weapon-free zone]] agreement.{{cite news|last1=MacAskill|first1=Ewen|last2=Traynor|first2=Ian|title=Saudis consider nuclear bomb|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/sep/18/nuclear.saudiarabia|accessdate=22 June 2017|work=The Guardian|date=18 September 2003}} It is believed that Saudi Arabia has been a major financier of [[Pakistan]]'s integrated [[Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction|nuclear program]] since 1974, a project begun under former [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]]. In 2003 it was reported that Saudi Arabia had taken the "strategic decision" to acquire "off-the-shelf" atomic weapons from Pakistan, according to senior American officials.{{cite news|last1=Harnden|first1=Toby|last2=Lamb|first2=Christina|title=Saudis 'to get nuclear weapons'|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/saudis-to-get-nuclear-weapons-v85860g8bp3|work=The Times|date=17 May 2015|accessdate=22 June 2017}} In 2003, ''[[The Washington Times]]'' reported that Pakistan and Saudi Arabia had entered a secret agreement on nuclear cooperation to provide the Saudis with nuclear weapons technology in return for access to cheap oil for Pakistan.{{cite news|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/org/news/2003/031022-pakistan_saudi-arabia.htm|title=Pakistan, Saudi Arabia in secret nuke pact: Islamabad trades weapons technology for oil|last=De Borchgrave|first=Arnaud|work=The Washington Times|date=22 October 2003}} Following several years of negotiations for a [[Iran nuclear deal framework|nuclear deal framework]] between Iran and the [[P5+1]] countries, the [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]] (JCPOA) was signed in 2015. The deal raised concerns for Saudi Arabia, which saw it as a step toward reducing Iran's international isolation and potentially exacerbating the proxy conflict.{{cite news|title=The 'Cold War' between Iran and Saudi Arabia is heating up. Here are 5 things you should know about it.|url=https://www.pri.org/stories/2017-11-12/cold-war-between-iran-and-saudi-arabia-heating-here-are-5-things-you-should-know|accessdate=15 November 2017|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=12 November 2017}} However, Riyadh did not publicly denounce the deal at the time as Israel did.{{cite news|last1=Hafezi|first1=Parisa|last2=Charbonneau|first2=Louis|last3=Irish|first3=John|last4=Mohammed|first4=Arshad|title=Iran deal reached, Obama hails step towards 'more hopeful world'|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear/iran-deal-reached-obama-hails-step-towards-more-hopeful-world-idUSKCN0PM0CE20150714|accessdate=20 March 2018|agency=Reuters|date=13 July 2015}} In 2018, [[Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia|Crown Prince]] [[Mohammad bin Salman]] stated that Saudi Arabia would move to obtain nuclear weapons if Iran's program is successful.{{cite news|title=Saudi crown prince: If Iran develops nuclear bomb, so will we|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/saudi-crown-prince-mohammed-bin-salman-iran-nuclear-bomb-saudi-arabia/|accessdate=16 March 2018|agency=CBS News|date=15 March 2018}} He led a delegation to the United States to meet with [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]] officials to discuss mutual concerns, including a potential US withdrawal from the Iran nuclear agreement.{{cite news|last1=Macias|first1=Amanda|title=Saudi crown prince, Trump to hold 'critical' talks on Iran nuclear deal|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/19/saudi-crown-prince-trump-to-hold-critical-talks-on-iran-nuclear-deal.html|accessdate=20 March 2018|agency=[[CNBC]]|date=19 March 2018}} In April 2018, Israeli [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] gave a televised speech accusing Iran of covertly continuing the [[AMAD Project]] in violation of the JCPOA.{{cite news|last1=Landau|first1=Noa|title=Netanyahu: Iran Nuclear Deal Is Based on Lies – Here's the Proof|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/pm-expected-to-reveal-how-iran-cheated-world-on-nuke-program-1.6045300|accessdate=14 May 2018|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=30 April 2018}} [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump|Trump]] announced on 8 May 2018 that the United States would [[United States withdrawal from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action|unilaterally withdraw]] from the JCPOA and reinstate previous [[sanctions against Iran]] in addition to imposing new sanctions.{{cite news|last1=Landler|first1=Mark|title=Trump Withdraws U.S. From 'One-Sided' Iran Nuclear Deal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/08/world/middleeast/trump-iran-nuclear-deal.html|accessdate=8 May 2018|work=The New York Times|date=8 May 2018}} In anticipation of the decision, Iranian [[President of Iran|President]] [[Hassan Rouhani|Rouhani]] stated that Iran would remain in the deal if the remaining parties did the same, but was otherwise vague on how the country would respond to the US decision.{{cite news|title=In Case Of US Withdrawal Iran Will Stay In Nuclear Deal, If Others Also Stay|url=https://en.radiofarda.com/a/29213598.html|accessdate=8 May 2018|agency=[[Radio '''David James Wilkie''' (9 July 1949 – 30 November 1984) was a [[Wales|Welsh]] taxi driver who was killed during the [[UK miners' strike (1984–1985)|miners' strike]] in the [[United Kingdom]], when two striking miners [[criminal rock throwing|dropped a concrete block]] from a footbridge onto his taxi whilst he was driving a strike-breaking miner to work. The attack caused a widespread revulsion at the extent of violence in the dispute. The two miners were convicted of [[murder]] but the charge was reduced to [[manslaughter]] on appeal, becoming a [[leading case]] on the issue of the difference between the two offences.
==Background== David Wilkie was born on 9 July 1949.{{cn|date=September 2011}} He was working in [[Treforest]], [[Mid Glamorgan]] as a taxi driver, driving a [[Ford Cortina]] for City Centre Cars, based in [[Bute Street (Cardiff)|Bute Street]], Cardiff.<ref name="Times">Tim Jones, "Two miners charged with murder of taxi driver", ''The Times'', 1 December 1984.</ref> He was regularly engaged in driving non-striking miners to work, as the bitter industrial dispute had made them targets for physical retaliation by those miners who were on strike. The [[Merthyr Tydfil]] area was said to be the strongest in support of the strike of any mining area in Britain; it is situated in [[South Wales]], where a large percentage of Britain's remaining coalmines were situated.<ref name="Times" /> There had not been much mass picketing in South Wales during the conflict, as there had been in many parts of England, because there had been so few strikebreakers.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Adeney |first1=Martin |last2=Lloyd |first2=John |date=1988 |title=The Miners' Strike 1984-5: Loss Without Limit |location=London |page=124 |publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul|isbn=0-7102-1371-9 }}</ref>
==Killing== On 30 November 1984, Wilkie's fare was David Williams, who lived in [[Rhymney]] and worked at the [[Merthyr Vale]] mine, six miles away. Wilkie was driving the same route as he had done for the previous ten days. He was accompanied by two police cars and a motorcycle outrider, and had just turned on to the [[A465 road]] north of Rhymney at the Rhymney Bridge roundabout, when two striking miners dropped a {{convert|46|lb|adj=on}}<ref name="Trial">Tim Jones, "Miner's taxi driver killed in minutes by 46 lb concrete block, QC says", ''The Times'', 8 May 1985.</ref> concrete block from a bridge 27 feet over the road. Wilkie died at the scene from multiple injuries; Williams escaped with minor injuries.<ref name="Times" />
==Reaction== The incident led to a decrease in public support for the striking miners, and to an increase in the number of workers in other industries who crossed miners' picket lines (e.g. at power plants).<ref>{{cite book |last1=Adeney |first1=Martin |last2=Lloyd |first2=John |date=1988 |title=The Miners' Strike 1984-5: Loss Without Limit |location=London |pages=150–151 |publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul|isbn=0-7102-1371-9 }}</ref>
[[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Margaret Thatcher]] said, "My reaction is one of anger at what this had done to a family of a person only doing his duty and taking someone to work who wanted to go to work." [[Kim Howells]], speaking for the South Wales [[National Union of Mineworkers (Great Britain)|National Union of Mineworkers]], blamed the attack on the attempts to persuade miners to return to work.<ref name="Times" /> [[Arthur Scargill]] said he had been "deeply shocked by the tragedy" of Wilkie's death.<ref name="Scargill">"Scargill shocked by 'tragic death'", ''The Times'', 1 December 1984.</ref>
Labour Party leader [[Neil Kinnock]] was scheduled to appear at a Labour Party rally alongside Scargill in [[Stoke-on-Trent]] on the day of the tragedy.<ref name="LWL294">{{cite book |last1=Adeney |first1=Martin |last2=Lloyd |first2=John |date=1988 |title=The Miners' Strike 1984-5: Loss Without Limit |location=London |publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul |page=294 |isbn=0-7102-1371-9 }}</ref> Kinnock's speech developed into an argument with some hecklers who saw him as having betrayed the NUM by failing to support the strike.<ref name="LWL294"/> Kinnock began by saying, "We meet here tonight in the shadow of an outrage."<ref name="LWL294"/> When interrupted, Kinnock accused the hecklers of "living like parasites off the struggle of the miners."<ref name="LWL294"/> As Kinnock went on to denounce the lack of the ballot, the violence against strikebreakers and the tactical approach of Scargill, he was asked by hecklers what he had done for the striking miners.<ref name="LWL295">{{cite book |last1=Adeney |first1=Martin |last2=Lloyd |first2=John |date=1988 |title=The Miners' Strike 1984-5: Loss Without Limit |location=London |publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul |page=295 |isbn=0-7102-1371-9 }}</ref> Kinnock shouted back, "Well, I was not telling them lies. That's what I was not doing during that period."<ref name="LWL295"/> This was a thinly-veiled attack on Scargill, whom he later admitted that he detested.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2004/02_february/27/coal_war.shtml BBC Press Office – Kinnock detests Scargill – 27 February 2004]</ref>
Wilkie lived with his fiancée Janice Reed, who was the mother of his two-year-old daughter and was pregnant with a baby who was born six weeks later. He also had a 12-year-old daughter and a five-year-old son by a previous partner.<ref name="Victim">Tim Jones, "Unlikely killers in a bitter dispute", ''The Times'', 17 May 1985.</ref> Funds were opened to help the family; among the donors was philanthropist [[John Paul Getty, Jr.|Paul Getty]].<ref name="Getty">"Dispute in the coalfields", ''The Times'', 19 December 1984.</ref> The [[Roy Davies|Bishop of Llandaff]] led Wilkie's funeral service; he called for "some sort of moratorium" and a return to work by the miners in return for an impartial board to investigate conditions in the coal industry.<ref name="Bishop">Tim Jones, "Bishop's plea as driver is buried", ''The Times'', 12 December 1984.</ref>
==Murder trial==
The two men who caused Wilkie's death, Dean Hancock and Russell Shankland, were found guilty of murder by a majority verdict on 16 May 1985 (by which time the strike had ended) and sentenced to life imprisonment.<ref name=OTDMay16>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/16/newsid_2512000/2512469.stm Miners jailed for pit strike murder], BBC News online (16 May 1985)</ref><ref name="Verdict">Tim Jones, "Miners get life for taxi murder", ''The Times'', 17 May 1985.</ref> A third man, Anthony Williams, who had been present on the bridge but was found to have actively discouraged them from dropping the concrete block, was acquitted.<ref name="Dismissed">Rupert Morris, "Welsh officials to meet over dismissed pitman", ''The Times'', 24 June 1985.</ref> The life sentences caused an outcry among the striking miners, who felt that the death of Wilkie was not a deliberate act; the strike had ended by the time the verdict was brought in, but 700 miners at Merthyr Vale walked out on hearing the news. A third miner, Dean Williams, was cleared of conspiracy to cause serious injury.<ref name="Wildcat strike">Tim Jones, "Miners walk out over life terms", ''The Times'', 18 May 1985.</ref>
Russell Shankland's solicitor was critical of Scargill's attitude. He referred to the strike as "a war" and said with regards to Scargill, "In that war there were generals, and they stood outside the law and they left Russell Shankland outside the law."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/16/newsid_2512000/2512469.stm BBC on this day, 16 May 1985, Miners jailed for pit strike murder]</ref>
On appeal, their convictions were reduced to manslaughter, and their life sentences were replaced with eight-year prison terms, of which they would serve just over half. The [[Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales|Lord Chief Justice]], [[Geoffrey Lane, Baron Lane|Lord Lane]], explained that the crime would be murder if the death was a "natural consequence" of the miners' actions, but the legal phrase "natural consequence" was potentially misleading without further explanation.<ref name="Appeal">Frances Gibb, "Miners win murder charge appeal", ''The Times'', 1 November 1985.</ref> The appeal verdict of guilty to manslaughter was upheld in the [[Judicial functions of the House of Lords|House of Lords]], in the case ''[[R v Hancock]]''.<ref name="Lords">Frances Gibb, "Manslaughter verdicts are upheld on miners who killed taxi driver", ''The Times'', 13 December 1985.</ref> Hancock and Shankland were released on 30 November 1989,<ref name=OTDMay16/> which was coincidentally the fifth anniversary of Wilkie's death.
==Aftermath== [[Kim Howells]], the South Wales NUM official who commented on the killing of David Wilkie, later became a [[Member of Parliament]] for the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and served as a minister in the [[Blair government]] and later became chair of the [[Intelligence and Security Committee]], a committee of parliamentarians that oversees the work of Britain's intelligence and security agencies. In 2004 he said that when he heard that a taxi driver had been killed, he thought "hang on, we've got all those records we've kept over in the NUM offices, there's all those maps on the wall, we're gonna get implicated in this". He then destroyed "everything", because he feared a police raid on the union offices.<ref name="Destruction">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/3435161.stm "Howells' strike papers admission – inquiry"], BBC News, 27 January 2004.</ref>
The killing is referenced in the [[Roger Waters]] songs , "Who Needs Information" and "Me or Him", on his 1984 ''[[Radio K.A.O.S.]]'' album.
