{{about|the opera by [[Hans Pfitzner]] (1917)|the opera by Johann Sachs (1886)|Johann Sachs}} {{Infobox opera | name = Palestrina | type = ''Musikalische Legende'' ([[Opera]]) | composer = {{nowrap|[[Hans Pfitzner]]}} | image = File:Hans Pfitzner by Wanda von Debschitz-Kunowski, ca 1910.jpg | caption = Hans Pfitzner, the composer of the opera, by Wanda von Debschitz-Kunowski, ca 1910 | librettist = Hans Pfitzner | language = German | premiere_date = {{Start date|1917|06|12|df=y}} | premiere_location = [[Prinzregententheater]], [[Munich]] }} '''''Palestrina''''' is an opera by the German composer [[Hans Pfitzner]], first performed in 1917. The composer referred to it as a ''Musikalische Legende'' (musical legend), and wrote the [[libretto]] himself, based on a legend about the [[Renaissance]] musician [[Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina]], who saves the art of contrapuntal music ([[polyphony]]) for the Church in the sixteenth century, through his composition of the ''[[Missa Papae Marcelli]]''. The wider context is that of the European [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]] and the role of music in relation to it. The character of [[Charles Borromeo|Cardinal Borromeo]] is depicted, and a General Congress of the [[Council of Trent]] is the centrepiece of Act II. The conductor of the premiere was [[Bruno Walter]]. On 16 February 1962, the day before he died, Walter ended his last letter with: ''"Despite all the dark experiences of today I am still confident that ''Palestrina'' will remain. The work has all the elements of immortality"''.Liner notes to the Rafael Kubelik/Nicolai Gedda/Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau DG recording == Critical appreciation== Claire Taylor-Jay has discussed Pfitzner's depiction of the political relationship between Palestrina and the Council of Trent, in the light of several German "artist-operas" such as [[Paul Hindemith]]'s ''[[Mathis der Maler (opera)|Mathis der Maler]]''.Claire Taylor-Jay, ''The Artist-Operas of Pfitzner, Krenek, and Hindemith: Politics and the Ideology of the Artist'', Aldershot: Ashgate, 2004. [[Mosco Carner]] has written on Pfitzner's own expression of the role of spontaneous inspiration in composition, as expressed in ''Palestrina''.Mosco Carner, "Pfitzner v. Berg, or Inspiration v. Analysis". ''The Musical Times'', '''118(1611)''', pp. 379-380 (May 1977). Several scholarly articles have delved into Pfitzner's musical and ideological conservatism, as expressed in this opera.[[Michael Steinberg (music critic)|Michael P. Steinberg]], [http://mq.oxfordjournals.org/content/85/1/53.full.pdf+html "Opera and Cultural Analysis: The Case of Hans Pfitzner's Palestrina".] (Subscription Access) ''[[The Musical Quarterly]]'', '''85''', 53-62 (2001).Leon Botstein, [http://mq.oxfordjournals.org/content/85/1/63.full.pdf+html "Pfitzner and Musical Politics".] (Subscription Access) ''[[The Musical Quarterly]]'', '''85''', 63-75 (2001). Gottfried Scholz has written of Pfitzner's depiction of the title character as a surrogate for himself.Gottfried Scholz (translated Irene Zedlacher), [http://mq.oxfordjournals.org/content/85/1/76.full.pdf+html "The Image of Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina in Pfitzner's Palestrina".] (Subscription Access) ''[[The Musical Quarterly]]'', '''85''', 76-84 (2001). Karen Painter has discussed commentary on the opera in [[Nazi Germany]].Karen Painter, [http://mq.oxfordjournals.org/content/85/1/117.full.pdf+html "Symphonic Ambitions, Operatic Redemption: Mathis der Maler and Palestrina in the Third Reich".] (Subscription Access) ''[[The Musical Quarterly]]'', '''85''', 117-166 (2001). ==Performance history== The work was first performed at the [[Prinzregententheater]], [[Munich]] on 12 June 1917. The title role was created by the tenor [[Karl Erb]].A photograph in Volume I of ''[[The Record of Singing]]'' shows the [[East Prussian]] tenor [[Felix Senius]] (1868-1913) in the title-role Palestrina. The first public performance was indeed in 1917, yet Senius died in 1913, so Erb was the first to perform the part. M. Scott, ''The Record of Singing'', I (Duckworth, London 1977), pp. 204-205, Fig 179. Pfitzner wrote in his copy of the score:
'Ich erachte es als einen der seltenen Glücksumstände in meinem Künstlerleben, dass mein grösstes Werk bei seinem ersten Erscheinen in der Welt für seine Haupt- und Titelrolle einen solch idealen Vertreter gefunden hat, wie Sie, lieber Karl Erb es sind. Ihr Name ist mit diesem Stück deutscher Kunst fur alle Zeiten ruhmreich verbunden.'M. Müller-Gögler, ''Karl Erb: Das Leben eines Sängers'' (Franz Huber, Offenburg c.1948), 81.
''(I consider it as one of the very occasional fortunate circumstances in my life as an artist, that my greatest work at its first appearance in the world has found for its chief and title role such an ideal interpreter as you, dear Karl Erb, are. Your name is for all time praiseworthily united with this piece of German art.)''
In the original performances, [[Maria Ivogün]] (later wife of Karl Erb) sang the role of Ighino, [[Fritz Feinhals]] and Dr [[Emil Schipper]] sang Borromeo, [[Willi Birrenkoven]] was Budoja,L. Riemens, Schumann and Brahms Lieder on record (HMV, Hayes 1983), 8. and [[Bruno Walter]] conducted. More recently the role of Palestrina has been played by [[Julius Patzak]], a successor to the style of tenor singing developed or maintained by Karl Erb. ''Palestrina'' was Pfitzner's most successful opera and is still regularly performed in German-speaking countries, though revivals abroad are rarer. The first UK performance was a semi-professional production in 1981 at Abbey Opera, and the first fully professional UK production was at the [[Royal Opera House]], [[Covent Garden]], in 1997.Guy Rickards, "First Performances: Pfitzner's 'Palestrina'". ''Tempo'' (New Ser.), '''201''', pp. 35-37 (July 1997). ==Main roles== {| class="wikitable" !Role !Voice type !Premiere Cast, 12 June 1917
(Conductor: [[Bruno Walter]]) |- |[[Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina]] |[[tenor]] |[[Karl Erb]] |- |Lukrezia, ''his wife, recently died'' |[[contralto]] |[[Luise Willer]] |- |Ighino, ''his son'' |[[soprano]] |[[Maria Ivogün]] |- |Silla, ''his pupil'' |[[mezzo-soprano]] |[[Emmy Krüger]] |- |Bernardo Novagerio, ''cardinal legate'' |tenor |[[Paul Kuhn (tenor)|Paul Kuhn]] |- |Bishop of Budoja |tenor |Willi Birrenkoven |- |[[Carlo Borromeo]], ''a Roman cardinal'' |[[baritone]] |Fritz Feinhals |- |Giovanni Morone, ''cardinal legate'' |baritone |[[Friedrich Brodersen]] |- |Count Luna, ''ambassador of the King of Spain'' |baritone |Alfons Gustav Schützendorf |- |[[Pope Pius IV]] |[[Bass (vocal range)|bass]] |[[Paul Bender (bass)|Paul Bender]] |- |Bishop [[Ercole Severolus]], ''Master of Ceremonies of the Council of Trent'' |[[bass-baritone]] |Alfred Bauerberger |- |Cardinal [[Christoph Madruscht]], ''Prince Bishop of Trent'' |bass |Max Gillman |- |Theophilus, ''Bishop of Imola'' |tenor | |- |The Cardinal of Lorraine |bass | |- |[[Abdisho IV Maron|Abdisu]], ''Patriarch of Assyria'' |tenor | |- |[[Anton Brus von Müglitz]], ''[[Archbishop of Prague]]'' |bass | |- |Avosmediano, ''Bishop of Cadiz'' |bass-baritone | |- |} == Synopsis == [[Image:Carlo Borromeo.jpg|thumb|250px|right| The future Saint Charles Borromeo]] ===Act One=== ''A room in Palestrina's house, Rome, around 1560''
(Scene 1) Palestrina's student Silla is trying over a secular lyric he has written, and planning to make a new life in [[Florence]], where he hopes to find his own voice as a singer and song-writer. [[Rome]] clings to its old-fashioned [[polyphony]] as closely as it defends its religion. (2) Ighino and Silla discuss their singing: Silla thinks a singer should stand alone, but Ighino thinks that real strength lies subordinating the individual self to the larger complex idea. He is sad because his father has lost heart: fame made others jealous, his marriage led the Pope to dismiss him, and his wife died knowing this. Since then Palestrina has written nothing. Silla sings to him his new song. (3) [[Charles Borromeo|Cardinal Borromeo]] is visiting Palestrina to explain that, because of growing secularism, the Pope plans to banish polyphony from [[Mass (Roman Rite)|the Mass]] and other offices, to burn the polyphonic masterpieces, and to revert entirely to the [[Gregorian chant]]. [[Emperor Ferdinand I]] hopes that a new polyphonic Mass can be written which will appease his fears. Borromeo wants Palestrina to undertake this, but, lacking the spirit, he refuses, and Borromeo leaves in anger. (4) Palestrina ponders his loss of faith and the weakness of love. In his despair, spirits of the great music-masters of previous ages appear and surround him. (5) The spirits tell Palestrina he belongs to their elect and must fulfil the task. He protests that in the modern consciousness ("Bewusstseins"), art cannot thrive. The spirits reply that this is his earthly mission: he must bring the light to his generation. They vanish. (6) In the darkness of his room angels begin to appear, singing the Mass, and his dead wife's spirit approaches. Not seeing them, Palestrina feels a surge of joy as the walls and ceiling open up to celestial light full of glory and angels, who sing the [[Gloria in Excelsis Deo|Gloria]]. In a creative transport Palestrina's pen is inspired, and as it all fades, he sinks exhausted to sleep, surrounded by sheets of music strewn all around. (7) Silla and Ighino enter while he sleeps, and find the music: it is a complete Mass, written in one night. Ighino rejoices, but Silla is sceptical. ===Act Two=== ''The Great Hall in Cardinal Madruscht's Palace in [[Trento|Trent]]''
(Scene 1) Bishop Severolus and the Papal legate Novagerio prepare the hall for the final General Congress of the Council of Trent. The Cardinal of Lorraine (who has reached compromise with the Pope) and Count Luna, representative of the King of Spain (favouring Protestantism) must be seated equally and without precedence. (2) Cardinal Madruscht and Novagerio discuss the coming decision while awaiting the delegates, and they greet Borromeo. (3) While delegates arrive, Borromeo and Novagerio talk politics: Emperor Ferdinand and his son Maximilian plan to have dominion of the Catholic world (including Germany) from the throne of Spain, in union with the [[King of the Romans|Kingship of Rome]], which is offered to [[Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian]] even though he is secretly inclined to [[Lutheranism]]. But the Pope will preserve dogma by the interpretation of imperial decrees. Borromeo explains that Palestrina has refused the commission for the new polyphonic Mass. Novagerio insists that Palestrina must be forced into subordination, or be crushed. (4) Cardinal Madruscht deplores Lorraine's compromise with Rome, and urges the Cardinal of [[Prague]] to stand fast for doctrinal Reforms. The Spanish arrive and look scornfully at the Italians and the Bishop of [[Budoja]]. Morone, the other papal legate, arrives and the Council begins. (5) Morone opens the meeting hoping for unity of purpose between Emperor, Pope and Princes. The question of the polyphonic Mass is raised, but Borromeo tells them it is unfinished. The issue of the vernacular Mass and [[breviary]] arises, but then Count Luna and Cardinal of Lorraine dispute precedence, and Budoja disrupts proceedings to deflect Count Luna's case. Chaos breaks out: the meeting is adjourned till the afternoon, when everything must be resolved. The delegates disperse. (6) Lorraine protests to Morone that he should have precedence, but Morone is angry that he has provoked Count Luna. Novagerio appeals to Lorraine to consider the interests of the Pope. Badoja makes himself objectionable. (7) The Spanish servants, and a group of German and Italian servants, shout abuse at each other and a battle with daggers ensues. Cardinal Madruscht appears with a troop of soldiers, and commands them to shoot to kill. A volley is fired, and many fall dead and wounded: all the survivors are seized and carried off for torture. ===Act Three=== ''Palestrina's house in Rome, as in the First Act.''
(Scene 1) Palestrina, aged and very tired, waits in his room with Ighino and some choristers. Borromeo imprisoned him for refusing the commission, but Ighino handed the music of the Mass over to save his father from the hangman. Now it is being sung before the Pope. Ighino begs his father to reawaken to life and to embrace the son who loves him. Suddenly the voices of singers from the Papal chapel are heard from the street singing 'Evviva Palestrina, the Saviour of Music!' (2) Papal singers come into the room, saying how greatly the Mass has pleased everyone. [[Pope Pius IV]] himself enters with eight Cardinals (including Borromeo), Palestrina kneels, and the Pope asks him to return and lead the [[Sistine Choir]] until the end of his days. Then they leave, but Borromeo remains and prostrates himself in tears, begging Palestrina's forgiveness. Palestrina raises him up, kisses him on the cheek and embraces him, for both are shattered vessels that must be filled with the breath of love. Borromeo, much chastened, departs: Ighino embraces his father, and asks if he will now be happy. Silla has gone to Florence, but Ighino will remain: in joy the boy rushes out into the street. Palestrina looks at his wife's portrait, and with an expression of devotion to God sits at the organ and begins to play. ==Recordings== * [[Deutsche Grammophon]] 427 417-2 (CD reissue): [[Nicolai Gedda]], [[Karl Ridderbusch]], Bernd Weikl, Herbert Steinbach, [[Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau]], Victor von Halem, John van Kesteren, Peter Meven, [[Hermann Prey]], Friedrich Lenz, [[Adalbert Kraus]], Franz Mazura, [[Helen Donath]], [[Brigitte Fassbaender]], [[Gerd Nienstedt]]; Bavarian Radio Chorus; [[Tölzer Knabenchor]]; [[Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra]], [[Rafael Kubelík]], conductor * (Live off-air performance 1951), Opera D'Oro 3MCD 975.170 (CD reissue): [[Julius Patzak]], [[Hans Hotter]], [[Ferdinand Frantz]], Georg Wieter, [[Franz Klarwein]], Katja Sabo, Kathe Neuburg, [[Bavarian State Opera]] Chorus and Orchestra ([[Prinzregententheater]]), [[Robert Heger]], conductor * (Studio recording, [[Cologne]] 1952), Mytho Records 3CD 021.H060 (CD reissue): [[Julius Patzak]], [[Hans Hotter]], Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, [[Gottlob Frick]], [[Anny Schlemm]], [[Richard Kraus]], conductor * (Live recording, [[Berlin]] 1986, 1988), Berlin Classics 3CD 0310001: [[Peter Schreier]], Siegfried Lorenz, Ekkehard Wlaschiha, Fritz Hübner, Hans-Joachim Ketelsen, Peter-Jürgen Schmitd, Carola Nossek, Rosemarie Lang; Chor der Deutschen Staatsoper Berlin; Staatskapelle Berlin; [[Otmar Suitner]], conductor ==Bibliography== *''Viking Opera Guide'' edited by Amanda Holden (Viking, 1993) *M. Müller-Gögler, ''Karl Erb, Das Leben eines Sängers'' (Verlag Franz Huber, Offenburg c 1948). *H. Rosenthal and J. Warrack, ''The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Opera'' (London 1974). *M. Scott, ''[[The Record of Singing]] to 1914'' (Duckworth, London 1977). ==References== {{reflist}} *[http://www.amadeusonline.net/almanacco.php?Start=0&Giorno=12&Mese=06&Anno=1917&Giornata=&Testo=&Parola=Stringa Amadeus Almanac, accessed 13 November 2008] {{Hans Pfitzner}} {{Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:German-language operas]] [[Category:1917 operas]] [[Category:Operas]] [[Category:Operas by Hans Pfitzner]] [[Category:Operas set in Italy]] [[Category:Historical operas]]

page.title: Removal of the Stone of Scone in 1950

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Use British English|date=October 2017}}
On Christmas Day 1950, four Scottish students from the [[University of Glasgow]] ([[Ian Hamilton (lawyer)|Ian Hamilton]], [[Gavin Vernon]], Kay Matheson and Alan Stuart) removed the [[Stone of Scone]] from [[Westminster Abbey]] in [[London]] and took the Stone back to Scotland.<ref name="telegraph">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1457731/Gavin-Vernon.html |title=Gavin Vernon |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=26 March 2004 |accessdate=1 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="scotsman1">{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/defining-our-destiny-1-519098 |title=Defining our destiny |newspaper=[[The Scotsman]] |date=29 March 2004 |accessdate=1 January 2013}}</ref> The students were members of the [[Scottish Covenant Association]], a group that supported [[Scottish Home Rule|home rule]] for Scotland.<ref name="telegraph" /> In 2008 the incident was made into a film called ''[[Stone of Destiny (film)|Stone of Destiny]]''.<ref name="scotsman2">{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/film-review-stone-of-destiny-1-1438029 |title=Film review: Stone of Destiny |newspaper=The Scotsman |date=3 October 2008 |accessdate=1 January 2013}}</ref>
==Background== The Stone of Scone, the ancient Stone upon which Scottish monarchs had been crowned, was taken from [[Scone, Perthshire|Scone]] near [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]], Scotland by King [[Edward I of England]] (Longshanks) in 1296 during the struggles against English invasion, which historians call the [[Scottish Wars of Independence]] as a [[looting|spoil of war]], kept in Westminster Abbey in London and fitted into [[King Edward's Chair]].<ref name="destiny">{{cite web |url=http://www.edinburghcastle.gov.uk/highlights-stone-of-destiny |title=Stone of Destiny |publisher=[[Historic Scotland]] |year=2012 |accessdate=1 January 2013}}</ref> Subsequent [[England|English]] and then [[United Kingdom|British]] monarchs were crowned sitting upon the chair and Stone.<ref name="destiny" /> At the time, the Stone was viewed as a symbol of Scottish nationhood; by removing the Stone to London, Edward I was declaring himself 'King of the Scots'.<ref name="herald" />
In 1950, Ian Hamilton, a student at the [[University of Glasgow]], approached Gavin Vernon with a plan to remove the Stone of Scone from Westminster Abbey in London and return it to Scotland.<ref name="telegraph" /> The plan was funded by a [[Glasgow]] businessman, Robert Gray, who was a councillor on the [[Glasgow Corporation Tramways|Glasgow Corporation]].<ref name="herald" /><ref name="scotsman3">{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/scottish-news/top-stories/first-stone-raider-meets-his-final-destiny-1-519088 |title=First Stone raider meets his final destiny |newspaper=The Scotsman |date=29 March 2004 |accessdate=1 January 2013}}</ref> Vernon agreed to participate in the plan along with Kay Matheson and Alan Stuart who were also students in Glasgow.<ref name="herald" /> By removing the Stone the group hoped to promote their cause for Scottish [[devolution in the United Kingdom|devolution]] and to reawaken a sense of national identity amongst the Scottish people.<ref name="herald" /><ref name="hamilton" />
==Removal of the Stone of Scone== In December 1950, a few days before Christmas, the four students from Glasgow drove to London in two [[Ford Anglia]]s, a journey which took them eighteen hours.<ref name="herald">{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/gavin-vernon-engineer-who-helped-return-the-stone-of-destiny-to-scotland-1.89326 |title=Gavin Vernon Engineer who helped return the Stone of Destiny to Scotland |newspaper=[[The Herald (Glasgow)]] |date=1 April 2004 |accessdate=1 January 2013}}</ref> On arrival in London they had a brief meeting at [[Lyons Corner House]] and decided to make an immediate attempt at removing the Stone from the Abbey.<ref name="telegraph" /> Later that day Ian Hamilton hid under a trolley in the Abbey, but was caught by a nightwatchman after the Abbey doors had been closed, briefly questioned, and then let go.<ref name="telegraph" />
The following day Vernon and Stuart returned to Westminster Abbey and learned some information on the watchmen's shifts.<ref name="telegraph" /> In the middle of that night, the three men entered a works yard and gained entrance into [[Poet's Corner]].<ref name="telegraph" /> Reaching the Chapel containing the tomb of [[Edward I of England|Edward I]] and [[King Edward's Chair]], they pulled down the barrier.<ref name="telegraph" /> On removing the Stone from under the Chair, it crashed to the floor and broke into two pieces<ref name="telegraph" /> The three men, using Hamilton's coat, dragged the larger piece down the high altar steps, then Hamilton took the smaller piece to one of the cars waiting outside.<ref name="telegraph" />
Ian Hamilton placed the small piece of Stone in the boot of the car and got into the passenger seat.<ref name="telegraph" /> As he did this, Kay Matheson noticed a policeman in the gaslight; Hamilton and Matheson immediately fell into a lovers' clinch.<ref name="telegraph" /> The policeman stopped and the three proceeded to have a conversation even though it was 5 A.M.<ref name="telegraph" /> Having shared some jokes and a cigarette Matheson and Hamilton drove off to [[Victoria, London|Victoria]], Hamilton getting out on the way to walk back to the Abbey.<ref name="telegraph" />
On his arrival there was no sign of Vernon and Stuart, so he proceeded to drag the large piece of stone to the car himself.<ref name="telegraph" /> As he was driving away he saw Vernon and Stuart walking towards him.<ref name="telegraph" />
The stone was so heavy that the springs on the car were sagging, so Vernon, fearing the alarm had been raised, made his way to [[Rugby, Warwickshire]].<ref name="telegraph" /> Hamilton and Stuart drove to [[Kent]], hid the large piece of stone in a field and made their way back to Scotland.<ref name="telegraph" /> Matheson left her car, containing the small piece of the Stone, with a friend in the Midlands, and like Vernon made her way back to Scotland by train.<ref name="telegraph" /> On discovering that the Stone was missing, the authorities closed the border between Scotland and England for the first time in four hundred years.<ref name="telegraph" />
A fortnight later Hamilton and some friends – including John Josselyn, whose 21st great grandfather was, ironically, Edward I <ref>{{cite web|url=http://trees.ancestry.co.uk/tree/25017403/person/1650035497 | title=John Rodney Josselyn - Overview - Ancestry.co.uk}}</ref> – recovered the two pieces of stone and brought them to Glasgow.<ref name="herald" /> They hired a stonemason, Baillie [[Robert Gray (Scottish politician)|Robert Gray]], to mend the Stone.<ref name="herald" /> Gray placed a brass rod inside the Stone containing a piece of paper.<ref name="herald" /> To this day, nobody knows what was written on the piece of paper.<ref name="herald" />
In April 1951 the police received a tip-off and the Stone was found on the site of the High Altar at [[Arbroath Abbey]] where in 1320 the assertion of Scottish nationhood was made in the [[Declaration of Arbroath]].<ref name="telegraph" /> The Stone was returned to Westminster Abbey in February 1952.<ref name="herald" />
The police conducted an investigation with specific focus on Scotland.<ref name="herald" /> All four of the group were interviewed and all later confessed to their involvement with the exception of Ian Hamilton.<ref name="telegraph" /> The authorities decided not to prosecute as the potential for the event to become politicised was far too great.<ref name="telegraph" /> [[Hartley Shawcross, Baron Shawcross|Sir Hartley Shawcross]], addressing Parliament on the matter, said: "The clandestine removal of the Stone from Westminster Abbey, and the manifest disregard for the sanctity of the abbey, were vulgar acts of vandalism which have caused great distress and offence both in England and Scotland. I do not think, however, that the public interest required criminal proceedings to be taken."<ref name="times">{{cite news |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/319077062/13B6B8FC20016577E13/1?accountid=15842 |title=Gavin Vernon |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date=2 April 2004 |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref>
==Implications== To understand the implications of the raid, one must understand the political landscape in the United Kingdom just after the end of the [[Second World War]].<ref name="hamilton">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/3743946/Ian-Hamilton-on-Stone-of-Destiny-I-felt-I-was-holding-Scotlands-soul.html |title=Ian Hamilton on Stone of Destiny: I felt I was holding Scotland's soul |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=14 December 2008 |accessdate=1 January 2013}}</ref> The United Kingdom was a unified nation and even in an era of post-war austerity, devolution was not on the political agenda.<ref name="hamilton" /> At the time, the [[Scottish National Party]] had 0.7% of the vote, the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] had withdrawn its commitment to devolution, and the [[Unionist Party (Scotland)|Conservative Party]] was at the high point of its popularity in Scotland.<ref name="hamilton" /> The raid was completely unexpected and gave the cause of Scottish devolution and nationalism a brief sense of prominence in the public conscience throughout the United Kingdom and beyond.<ref name="scotsman1" />
The students became notorious for the daring heist and in Scotland they achieved nigh-on hero status, while in contrast the English were somewhat bewildered.<ref name="hamilton" /> The heist and the students became synonymous with the devolution and [[Scottish National Party|nationalist]] political movements in Scotland from 1950 onwards.<ref name="herald" />
Over time the incident encouraged a belief in change, throwing open to scrutiny the Union, which had existed since [[Acts of union 1707|1707]].<ref name="scotsman1" /> Long before the Stone was officially returned to Scotland in 1996 and the Scottish people voted for devolution in 1997, the removal of the Stone of Scone in 1950 contributed to those events.<ref name="scotsman1" />
== Portrayals in popular culture ==
The removal of the stone was the subject of a contemporary [[Scottish Gaelic language|Scottish Gaelic]] song by Donald MacIntyre, "''[[Òran na Cloiche]]''" ("The Song of the Stone"). Its return to England was the subject of an accompanying [[lament]], "''Nuair a Chaidh a' Chlach a Thilleadh''" ("When the Stone Was Returned").<ref>{{cite book |last=MacMillan |first=Somerled |date=1968 |title=Sporan Dhòmhnaill - Gaelic Poems and Songs by the late Donald Macintyre, the Paisley Bard |trans-title=Donald's Purse - Gaelic Poems and Songs by the late Donald Macintyre |url= |language=gd |location=Edinburgh |publisher=Scottish Academic Press |isbn= |page=xxvi}}</ref>
In 2008, Hamilton's book, ''The Taking of the Stone of Destiny'', was made into a film entitled ''[[Stone of Destiny (film)|Stone of Destiny]]''. The film depicted Hamilton (played by [[Charlie Cox]]) as the protagonist leading a team of students to reclaim the [[Stone of Scone]]. Additionally, Hamilton had a small, [[cameo role]].<ref name="imdb">"[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1037156/ Stone of Destiny]," ''[[The Internet Movie Database]]''. ''(Retrieved 2010-01-09.)''</ref>
[[BBC Alba]] released an hourlong bilingual (Scottish Gaelic and English) dramatization of Kay Matheson's (played by [[Kathleen MacInnes]]) interrogation by the police. In this version Matheson pretends not to speak English.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HNJgudcRi64|title=AN CEASNACHADH - Interrogation of a Highland Lass|first=|last=Gaelic Filmz|date=19 February 2014|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
In ''[[Highlander: The Series]]'' the episode "The Stone of Scone" (1997) reveals the Stone of Destiny was swiped and duplicated by immortals: the Scotsman [[Duncan MacLeod]] and his friends [[Hugh Fitzcairn]] and [[Amanda (Highlander)|Amanda Darieux]]. A cover story involving students was concocted to conceal their involvement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/shows/highlander/the-stone-of-scone-55212/|title=Highlander: The Stone of Scone|first=|last=TV.com|website=TV.com}}</ref>
==See also== [[Scone Palace]]

{{redirect|Going through the motions||Going Through the Motions (disambiguation)}}
'''Setting up to fail''' is a phrase denoting a [[no-win situation]] designed in such a way that the person in the situation cannot succeed at the task which they have been assigned. It is considered a form of [[workplace bullying]].<ref>Stambor, Zak.[https://www.apa.org/monitor/julaug06/apathy.aspx "Bullying stems from fear, apathy."] ''APA.com''. Originally published in ''Monitor on Psychology''. American Psychological Association. July/August 2006, vol. 37, no. 7. p. 72</ref> There are also situations in which an organization or project is set up to fail.<ref name=skeptic/><ref name = "AusFent"/> and where individuals set themselves up to fail.<ref name=boyatzis/>
The first known documented use of "set up to fail" was in 1969 in the United States.<ref> [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=8-zQAAAAMAAJ&q=%22set+up+to+fail%22&dq=%22set+up+to+fail%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=4f4BVY6nKsTiU-CzgOAO&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBw Economic Opportunity Amendments of 1969: Hearings, Ninety-first Congress, First Session, on H.R. 513]</ref>
==In the workplace== Setting up to fail is a well-established [[workplace bullying]] tactic.<ref>Peyton, PR. ''Dignity at Work: Eliminate Bullying and Create a Positive Working Environment'' (2003)</ref><ref>Rayner C, Hoel H A. "Summary Review of Literature Relating to Workplace Bullying", ''Journal of Community & Applied Social Psychology'', volume 7, issue 3, pages 181–191, June 1997</ref><ref>Randle J Workplace Bullying in the NHS (2006)</ref> One technique is to overload with work, while denying the victim the authority to handle it and over-interfering;<ref>J-F Manzoni/J-L Barsoux, ''The Set-up-to-fail Syndrome'' (2007) p. 5 and p. 12</ref> another is the withholding of the information necessary to succeed.<ref>[[Tim Field]], ''Bully in Sight'', Success Unlimited (1996) pp. 63–7 {{ISBN|978-0-9529121-0-1}}</ref>
If a person puts another individual (usually a subordinate) in a [[Occupational stress|stressful]] situation in which failure is almost certain, this may be an aspect of [[bullying]] wherein the outcome can then be used to [[discrediting tactic|discredit]] and [[victim blaming|blame the victim]].<ref>[[Tim Field]], ''Bully in Sight'' Success Unlimited (1996) p. 43 {{ISBN|978-0-9529121-0-1}}</ref> Sometimes, this may involve the bully covertly sabotaging and [[social undermining|undermining]] an objective that may have otherwise been achievable. This type of bullying may be the result of the [[Projective identification|projection]] of the bully's own feelings of inadequacy onto the victim.<ref>S. White, ''An Introduction to the Psychodynamics of Workplace Bullying'' (2013) pp. 31–2</ref>
There can be cases where an employee is set up to fail because the stated goals of the task are considered harmful to the organization; an internal investigation is one example. Institutions may protect themselves by "going through the motions" of a sham investigation in which the findings conveniently fail to find any evidence of wrongdoing by the authorities involved with setting up the investigation.
==Bigotry== Minorities seeking acceptance into the mainstream are often concerned about being set up to fail in the face of covert institutional [[racism]] – something feared for example by the first black US [[naval officer]]s.<ref>Paul Stillwell/Colin L Powell, ''The Golden Thirteen'' (2003) p. 98 and p. 86</ref>
==Families== Parents may have excessive expectations for their children's academic success for instance, thus setting them up for failure by hoping they may solve their parents' problems for them.<ref>Debra Wesselmann, ''The Whole Parent'' (2003) p. 104</ref> The result may be to create a self-destructive syndrome in the child – the so-called [[Child (archetype)|Divine Child]] complex.<ref>Polly Young-Eisendrath, ''Women and Desire'' (London 2000) p. 107 and p. 113</ref>
==Therapy== Therapy may be sabotaged by either the client or the provider. The client, both hoping for and fearing the possibility of real help, may impose conditions on the therapy that all but guarantee its failure.<ref>Neville Symington, ''Narcissism'' (2003) p. 70</ref> Conversely, the helper, needing to keep clients in a state of dependency,<ref>P. Casement, ''Further Learning from the Patient'' (1990) p. 144</ref> may be threatened by the prospect of success/closure, and undermine the therapy accordingly.<ref>Eric Berne, ''Games People Play'' (1966) pp. 126–7</ref>
==Setting oneself up to fail<!--This section is linked from [[Impostor syndrome]]: do not rename without including an anchor to previous name ([[MOS:HEAD]])-->== A person setting themselves up for failure may do so because they have a [[fear of failure]], an unrealistic assessment of their own abilities, or because they are naive and uninformed regarding the abilities necessary to succeed. In some cases, an individual has an unjustified expectation that they will fail, a self-reinforcing negative spiral,<ref name=boyatzis>[[R. E. Boyatzis]]/A. McKee, ''Resonant Leadership'' (2005) p. 156</ref> or failure neurosis<ref name=enotes>{{cite web|last=De Mijolla|first=Alain|title=Failure neurosis|url=https://www.enotes.com/failure-neurosis-reference/failure-neurosis|publisher=Enotes|accessdate=8 April 2013}}</ref> – perhaps driven by a sense of guilt,<ref>Otto Fenichel, ''The Psychoanalytic Theory of Neurosis'' (1946) p. 506</ref> or by the [[Repetition compulsion|compulsion to repeat]] self-destructive behaviour.<ref>S, Freud, ''On Metapsychology'' (PFL 11) pp. 292–3</ref>
==In television== It is a tactic used in [[reality television]], where situations are engineered to produce certain results.<ref name = "AusFent">Fenton, Andrew and Anna Brain. [https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/television/insiders-say-sleep-deprivation-and-setting-contestants-up-to-fail-are-common-tricks-of-the-trade/story-fni0cjvj-1227514099525 "Insiders say sleep deprivation and setting contestants up to fail are common tricks of the trade"]. ''The Daily Telegraph'' (Australia). September 5, 2015. Accessed September 5, 2015. Originally from [https://www.news.com.au/entertainment/tv/insiders-say-sleep-deprivation-and-setting-contestants-up-to-fail-are-common-tricks-of-the-trade/story-fn8yvfst-1227514099525?sv=de7b067521996b03d5249c278376d647 ''news.com.au''].</ref> ''[[My Kitchen Rules]]'' contestant Emily Cheung told the reporter that "she believes the producers set them up for failure in the instant restaurant round when they were told at 6 o'clock the night before they had to cook a Chinese dish they weren't familiar with—smoked quail—and scored 2 out of 10".<ref name = AusFent/> The same article goes on to state that, "A former Apprentice contestant feels similarly [[Psychological manipulation|manipulated]], saying he believed producers had already decided who they wanted to win when he was eliminated."<ref name = AusFent/>
==9/11 Commission== [[9/11 Commission]] member [[Lee H. Hamilton]] was quoted as saying that "the Commission was set up to fail"; some observers interpreted this as meaning that he was dissatisfied with the results of the [[9/11 Commission Report]], and conspiracy theory developed. The context of the interview transcript indicates that Hamilton said his reasoning was that "Tom Kean and I were substitutes—Henry Kissinger and George Mitchell were the first choices; we got started late; we had a very short time frame—indeed, we had to get it extended; we did not have enough money—3 million dollars to conduct an extensive investigation. We needed more, we got more, but it took us a while to get it."<ref name=skeptic>[http://other.skepticproject.com/articles/quotes/view/27/911-commission-member-said-commission-was-setup-t/ Quotes - 9/11 Commission member said Commission was set up to fail].''Skeptic Project.'' Accessed September 5, 2015.</ref>
==In popular culture== * In the film ''[[The Producers (1968 film)|The Producers]]'', theater show producers tried to set up a show to fail by intentionally including bad taste themes. * In the film ''[[The Hudsucker Proxy]]'' a corporation attempts to find a "dimwit, a proxy, a pawn, somebody we can really push around" for CEO, in order to manipulate the stock price to crash so that the board of directors can gain greater control of outstanding shares. * [[Reginald Perrin#Series Two .2821 September – 2 November 1977.29|Reginald Perrin]] tried to set himself up to fail by starting a shop called Grot, which only sold useless goods.

{{Refimprove|date=August 2009}} {{About-distinguish2|the siege that occurred in 589–587 BC|the first siege by Nebuchadnezzar, see [[Siege of Jerusalem (597 BC)]]}} {{otheruses|Siege of Jerusalem (disambiguation){{!}}Siege of Jerusalem}} {{Infobox military conflict |image = |caption = [[Line engraving]] of the destruction of Jerusalem from an 18th century edition of [[Josephus]]' ''[[Antiquities of the Jews]]''. The destruction of [[Solomon's Temple]] is visible in the background. |conflict = Siege of Jerusalem |partof = the [[Jewish–Babylonian war]] (601–586 BC) |date = 589 to 587 BC |place = [[Jerusalem]] |result = Babylonian victory, destruction of [[Jerusalem]], fall of [[Kingdom of Judah]] |combatant1 = [[Kingdom of Judah]] |combatant2=[[Neo-Babylonian Empire]] |commander1 = [[Zedekiah]] |commander2 = [[Nebuchadnezzar II]] |strength1 = Much fewer |strength2 = Unknown |casualties1 = Many slain, 4,200 others taken to captivity |casualties2 = Unknown}} {{Campaignbox Campaigns of the Israelites}} {{Campaignbox Campaigns of Nebuchadnezzar II}} In 589 BC, [[Nebuchadnezzar II]] laid siege to [[Jerusalem]], culminating in the destruction of the city and [[Temple in Jerusalem|its temple]] in the summer of 587 or 586 BC.
==Siege== Following the [[Siege of Jerusalem (597 BC)|siege of 597 BC]], the Neo-[[Babylonia]]n king Nebuchadnezzar installed [[Zedekiah]] as tributary [[king of Judah]], at the age of 21. However, Zedekiah revolted against Babylon, and entered into an alliance with Pharaoh [[Apries|Hophra]], the king of [[Late Period of ancient Egypt|Egypt]]. Nebuchadnezzar responded by invading [[Kingdom of Judah|Judah]]<ref>{{bibleverse|2|Kings|25:1|HE}}</ref> and began a siege of [[Jerusalem]] in December 589 BC. During this siege, the duration of which was either 18 or 30 months,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Malamat|first1=Abraham|title=The Last Kings of Judah and the Fall of Jerusalem: An Historical – Chronological Study|journal=Israel Exploration Journal|date=1968|volume=18|issue=3|pages=137–56|jstor=27925138|quote=The discrepancy between the length of the siege according to the regnal years of Zedekiah (years 9–11), on the one hand, and its length according to Jehoiachin's exile (years 9–12), on the other, can be cancelled out only by supposing the former to have been reckoned on a Tishri basis, and the latter on a Nisan basis. The difference of one year between the two is accounted for by the fact that the termination of the siege fell in the summer, between Nisan and Tishri, already in the 12th year according to the reckoning in Ezekiel, but still in Zedekiah's 11th year which was to end only in Tishri.}}</ref> the Bible describes the city as enduring horrible deprivation.<ref>{{bibleverse|2|Kings|25:3|HE}}; {{bibleverse||Lamentations|4:4|HE}}, {{bibleverse-nb||Lamentations|5|HE}}, {{bibleverse-nb||Lamentations|9|HE}}</ref> After completion of the eleventh year of Zedekiah's reign,<ref>{{bibleverse||Jeremiah|1:3|HE}}</ref> Nebuchadnezzar broke through Jerusalem's walls, conquering the city. Zedekiah and his followers attempted to escape but were captured on the plains of [[Jericho]] and taken to [[Riblah]]. There, after seeing his sons killed, Zedekiah was blinded, bound, and taken captive to Babylon,<ref>{{bibleverse|2|Kings|25:1–7|HE}}; {{bibleverse|2|Chronicles|36:12|HE}}; {{bibleverse||Jeremiah|32:4–5|HE}}; {{bibleverse-nb||Jeremiah|34:2–3|HE}}; {{bibleverse-nb||Jeremiah|39:1–7|HE}}; {{bibleverse-nb||Jeremiah|52:4–11|HE}}</ref> where he remained a prisoner until his death.
After the fall of Jerusalem, the Babylonian general, Nebuzaraddan, was sent to complete its destruction. Jerusalem was plundered, and [[Solomon's Temple]] was destroyed. Most of the elite were taken into [[Babylonian captivity|captivity in Babylon]]. The city was razed to the ground. Only a few people were permitted to remain to tend to the land.<ref>{{bibleverse||Jeremiah|52:16|HE}}</ref>
The Jew [[Gedaliah]] was made governor of the remnant of Judah, the [[Yehud Province]], with a [[Chaldea]]n guard stationed at [[Mizpah in Benjamin|Mizpah]].<ref>{{bibleverse|2|Kings|25:22–24|HE}}; {{bibleverse||Jeremiah|40:6–8|HE}}</ref> The Bible reports that, on hearing this news, Jews who had fled to [[Moab]], [[Ammon]], [[Edom]], and in other countries returned to Judah.<ref>{{bibleverse||Jeremiah|40:11–12|HE}}</ref> Gedaliah was assassinated by [[Ishmael son of Nethaniah]] two months later, and the population that had remained and those who had returned then fled to Egypt for safety.<ref>{{bibleverse|2|Kings|25:25–26|HE}}, {{bibleverse||Jeremiah|43:5–7|HE}}</ref> In Egypt, they settled in [[Migdol]] (it is uncertain where the Bible is referring to here, probably somewhere in the Nile Delta), [[Tahpanhes]], [[Memphis, Egypt|Memphis]] (called Noph), and [[Pathros]] (the vicinity of [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]]).<ref>{{bibleverse||Jeremiah|44:1|HE}}</ref>
==Chronological notes== {{See also|Jeconiah}} [[File:Zedekiah is chained and brought before Nebuchadnezzar.jpg|thumb|Zedekiah is chained and brought before [[Nebuchadnezzar II|Nebuchadnezzar]], from [[Petrus Comestor]]'s "[[Bible Historiale]]," 1670.]] There has been some debate as to when the second siege of Jerusalem took place. There is no dispute that Jerusalem fell the second time in the summer month of Tammuz ({{bibleverse||Jeremiah|52:6|HE}}), but [[William F. Albright]] dates the end of Zedekiah's reign and the fall of Jerusalem to 587 BC, but [[Edwin R. Thiele]] offers 586 BC.<ref name=Thiele>Edwin Thiele, ''[[The Mysterious Numbers of the Hebrew Kings]]'', (1st ed.; New York: Macmillan, 1951; 2d ed.; Grand Rapids: Eerdmans, 1965; 3rd ed.; Grand Rapids: Zondervan/Kregel, 1983). {{ISBN|0-8254-3825-X}}, {{ISBN|9780825438257}}.</ref>
Thiele's reckoning is based on the presentation of Zedekiah's reign on an accession basis, which he asserts was occasionally used for the kings of Judah. In that case, the year that Zedekiah came to the throne would be his ''zero''th year; his first full year would be 597/596 BC, and his eleventh year, the year that Jerusalem fell, would be 587/586 BC. Since Judah's regnal years were counted from Tishri in autumn, that would place the end of his reign and the capture of Jerusalem in the summer of 586 BC.<ref name=Thiele /><ref>Leslie McFall, "A Translation Guide to the Chronological Data in Kings and Chronicles," ''Bibliotheca Sacra'' 148 (1991) 45.</ref>
The [[Nebuchadnezzar Chronicle]] (BM 21946), published in 1956, indicates that Nebuchadnezzar captured Jerusalem the first time putting an end to the reign of [[Jeconiah|Jehoaichin]], on 2 Adar (16 March) 597 BC, in Nebuchadnezzar's seventh year.<ref>[[Donald Wiseman|D. J. Wiseman]], ''Chronicles of Chaldean Kings in the British Museum'' (London: Trustees of the British Museum, 1956) 73.</ref> Jeremiah 52:28–29 gives the relative periods for the end of the two sieges as Nebuchadnezzar's seventh and eighteenth years, respectively. (The same periods are elsewhere described at 2 Kings 24:12 and 2 Kings 25:8 as Nebuchadnezzar's eighth and nineteenth years, including his accession year.) Identification of Nebuchadnezzar's eighteenth year for the end of the siege places the event in the summer of 587 BC.

[[File:QuietClubbing Gatsby Party 4.08.16.jpg|thumb|QuietClubbing Gatsby Party in New York on April 8, 2016]] A '''silent disco''' or '''silent rave''' is an event where people dance to music listened to on wireless [[headphone]]s.<ref name="Oxford English Dictionary">{{cite web|url=http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/silent+disco|title=silent disco - Definition of silent disco in English by Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries - English}}</ref> Rather than using a [[speaker system]], music is broadcast via a radio transmitter with the signal being picked up by wireless headphone receivers worn by the participants. Those without the headphones hear no music, giving the effect of a room full of people dancing to nothing.
In the earliest days of silent discos, before 2005, there would be only one channel available to listen to music through. Over time, the technology moved along to where there were two, and later technology allowed for a third channel that three separate DJs could broadcast over at the same time.
Silent discos are popular at music festivals as they allow dancing to continue past noise curfews. Similar events are "mobile clubbing" gatherings, where a group of people dance to the music on their personal music players.
==History== [[Image:Silent house party san francisco.jpg|thumb|left|A silent house party in [[San Francisco, California]]]] An early reference in fiction is the 1969 Finnish science-fiction film ''Ruusujen Aika'' (''A Time of Roses''), where characters wear headsets during a party.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0138764/|title= IMDb "A Time of Roses"|publisher=|accessdate=|last=|first= | date=}}</ref>
The concept was used by eco-activists in the early 1990s, utilizing headphones at outdoor parties to minimize noise pollution and disturbance to the local wildlife.
In 1994, the [[Glastonbury Festival]] linked its on-site radio station to the video screen sited next to the Main Stage, allowing festival goers to watch late night [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] football and music videos on the giant screen after the sound curfew by using their own portable radios. The idea was the brainchild of the project manager from Proquip, who supplied the giant screen, and engineers from Moles Recording Studio in [[Bath, Somerset]], who were working with Radio Avalon.
In May 2000, [[BBC]] Live Music held a "silent gig" at [[Chapter Arts Centre]] in [[Cardiff]], where the audience listened to a band, Rocketgoldstar, and various DJs through headphones.<ref name="BBC Music Live events unfold">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/764290.stm|title=BBC News - ENTERTAINMENT - BBC Music Live events unfold|website=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
In May 2002 artist Meg Duguid hosted ''Dance with me...'' a silent dance party at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago]] where she created an outdoor club installation complete with velvet ropes and glow rope in which a DJ spun a transmission to wireless headsets that audience members put on and danced to.<ref>http:</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Molzahn|first1=Laura|title=Summer Solstice Celebration|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/summer-solstice-celebration/Content?oid=908938|website=Chicago Reader|accessdate=12 April 2017}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://megduguid.com/section/149646-Dance-with-me.html|title=Dance with me...|website=megduguid.com}}</ref> Duguid threw a second dance party at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago]] the following year, entitled Dueling DJs where two DJS simultaneously spun two separate musical transmissions various wireless headsets that audience members put on and danced to. This performance was repeated the following year (2004) at the [[Chicago Cultural Center]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Dueling DJs @ Cultural Center|url=http://www.gapersblock.com/slowdown/archives/2004/12/|website=Gapers Block: Slow Down Archive|accessdate=12 April 2017}}</ref>
The term "silent disco" has been in existence since at least 2005 with [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]] advertising such an event that year with DJ’s [[Motion Potion]], Quickie Mart and DJ medi4 and headphones provided by KOSS.<ref>{{cite news | title =Boogie Nights: 'Silent disco' is making itself heard | first =Robin A. | last =Rothman | url =http://www.mtv.com/news/1504012/bonnaroo-kicks-out-the-jams-thanks-to-dave-matthews-john-mayer-and-bo-bice/ | newspaper =[[MTV]] | date =June 13, 2005 | accessdate =June 13, 2005 }}</ref> In the Netherlands, the traveling arts and culture festival De Parade already featured a "stille disco" [silent disco] earlier, for example in 2003. <ref>{{cite web|last1=Schmitz|first1=Jowi|title=Amsterdams Parade-publiek bekijkt zichzelf|url=https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2003/08/05/amsterdams-parade-publiek-bekijkt-zichzelf-7649080-a812311|website=NRC.nl|publisher=NRC|accessdate=21 May 2018|language=Dutch|date=5 August 2003}}</ref> Dutch DJs Nico Okkerse and Michael Minton have been described as "the pioneers ... in the legend of silent disco" because they started "stille disco" events in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carroll|first1=Robert|title=A quiet night out|url=https://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/music/a-quiet-night-out-1.499140|website=The National|publisher=The National|accessdate=21 May 2018|date=19 November 2008}}</ref> Okkerse claims his company 433fm.com "created Silent Disco in 2002"<ref>{{cite web|title=Nico Okkerse|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/nico-okkerse-0b0191b/|website=LinkedIn|publisher=LinkedIn|accessdate=21 May 2018}}</ref> and its site does have photos from such events going back to at least 2003.<ref>{{cite web|title=Festival de Parade Museumpark|url=http://www.radio433.com/foto/detail.php?book=20030620&taal=|website=Radio433.com|publisher=433fm.com|accessdate=21 May 2018|date=2003}}</ref>
[[HUSHconcerts]] (previously, Silent Frisco) was the first company to produce a multi-city Silent Disco tour in 2008 with Silent Soundclash <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2008/jun/14/meltdownmassiveattack|title=Meltdown: Silent disco, big noise|last=Ojumu|first=Akin|date=2008-06-14|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2017-01-24}}</ref> kicking off at [[Winter Music Conference]] in Miami, followed by Atlanta, Athens, Savannah, Wilmington NC, Charlottesville Va, Baltimore, New York City, Syracuse, Pittsburgh and St. Louis. During this tour, the company became the first to produce American silent discos on a beach (Miami Beach) and a boat (the Rocksoff Cruise in New York Harbor).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jambands.com/news/2010/04/02/silent-soundclash-rana-eric-krasno-chapter-2-among-cruises-on-rocks-off-calendar|title=Silent Soundclash, RANA, Eric Krasno & Chapter 2 Among Cruises on Rocks Off Calendar|website=www.jambands.com|access-date=2017-01-24}}</ref>
The [[Oxford Dictionary Online]] added the term "silent disco" to their website in February 2011.<ref name="Oxford English Dictionary" /> As interest has increased, there has been a rise in the number of companies organizing parties and providing events with wireless headphones. Some companies have offered home kits.<ref name="craze">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/6142360/Silent-disco-craze-spreads.html|title=Silent disco craze spreads|last=Johnston|first=Ian|date=6 September 2009|work=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=7 June 2010}}</ref>
==Mobile clubbing== Another type of silent party, known as mobile clubbing, involves the gathering of a group of people in an unconventional location to dance to music which they provide themselves via a [[Portable audio player|portable music device]], such as an [[MP3 player]], listened to on headphones. These [[flash mob]] gatherings may involve hundreds of people, transforming public spaces into temporary clubbing areas, in which dancers listen to their personal playlists. To an observer it would appear that the participants are dancing for no apparent reason. Mobile clubbing events are organized using mass-emails, word-of-mouth or [[social networking]] websites such as [[Facebook]], or a combination of these methods.
The first event, organised by London-based artists Ben Cummins (also founder of Pillow Fight Club) and Emma Davis, was at London's [[Liverpool Street Station]] in September 2003.<ref name="Mobile Clubbing website">[http://www.mobile-clubbing.com/Seedsprouts/MobileClubbing/Display/EventList.aspx?period=past Mobile Clubbing website] retrieved on 2009-02-28</ref> Over the next five months there were a further five events at other London train stations including [[London Waterloo railway station|Waterloo]], [[Charing Cross railway station|Charing Cross]] and [[London Bridge station|London Bridge]].<ref name="Mobile Clubbing Instructions">[https://web.archive.org/web/20070501081916/http://www.mobile-clubbing.com/eventsWeb/public/mobileclubbing/mcInstructions.aspx Mobile Clubbing Instructions] retrieved on 2007-05-01</ref> By the end of 2008 there had been more than twenty of these events at similar venues throughout London, mostly train station concourses or other public spaces that lend themselves to expressive dancing and rapid dispersal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=409998&in_page_id=1770|title=i-Pod flashmobbers dance in their hundreds at station|publisher=}}</ref>
An event in 2007 at [[London Victoria station|Victoria Station]], [[London]] involved 4,000 participants.<ref>{{cite news | title = 4,000 flash mob dancers startle commuters at Victoria | first = Tim | last = Stewart | work = [[Evening Standard]] | date = 2007-04-05 | accessdate = 2007-05-03 | url = https://www.standard.co.uk/news/4000-flash-mob-dancers-startle-commuters-at-victoria-7203786.html }}</ref> The event was broken up by police two hours later.
==Headphone concert== [[File:Flaming Lips - headphone concert poster.png|thumb|left|A Flaming Lips poster promoting "The World's First Headphone Concerts"]] A headphone concert is a [[live music]] performance where the audience, in the same venue as the performing artist, listens to the music through headphones.<ref name="plug2005">{{cite web|title=[:]plug[:] (2005)|url=http://deletist.info/|work=deletist.info |accessdate=2016-08-23| date=2005-08-31 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050924230826/http://deletist.info/|archivedate=2005-09-24}}</ref> The idea originated in 1997 when [[Erik Minkkinen]],<ref>[[:fr:Sister Iodine]]</ref><ref name="placard2005">{{cite web|title=the placard headphone festival|url=http://www.leplacard.org/|work=leplacard.org |accessdate=2005-10-26| date=2005-08-31 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051026233655/http://www.leplacard.org/|archivedate=2005-10-26}}</ref> an electronic artist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://v2.nl/archive/people/erik-minkkinen|title=Erik Minkkinen|website=V2_Institute for the Unstable Media}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/76850-Erik-Minkkinen|title=Erik Minkkinen|website=Discogs}}</ref> from [[Paris]], streamed a live concert from his closet over the internet to three listeners in Japan.<ref name="wiredbyo">{{cite web|last=Axline|first=Keith|title=Fest Rocks With BYO Headphones|url=http://archive.wired.com/entertainment/music/news/2005/08/68682|work=Wired.com entertainment music news|publisher=wired magazine|accessdate=2016-08-23|date=2005-08-31|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160823160820/http://archive.wired.com/entertainment/music/news/2005/08/68682|archivedate=2016-08-23}}</ref> The concept led to a decentralized organization known as ''le placard'' ("the Cupboard"),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/#fr/en/Placard|title=Google Translate|website=translate.google.com}}</ref> which allowed anybody to establish a streaming or listening room.<ref name="wiredbyo"/>
The first headphone concert taking place in front of a live audience took place March 20, 1999, at the [[South by Southwest]] festival in [[Austin, Texas]]. The American psychedelic band [[The Flaming Lips]] used an FM signal generator at the venue and handed out mini [[FM radio]] receivers and headphones to each member of the audience. A normal speaker system was also used so the sound could also be felt. This continued on their "International Music Against Brain Degeneration Revue" tour with mixed results, with technical problems including dead batteries and intoxicated audience members having trouble tuning to the correct frequency.<ref name="warner press archive">{{cite web|last=Booker|first=Scott|title=Partly Accurate Flaming Lips News|url=http://www.wbr.com/flaminglips/cmp/marnov99.htm|work=Archived News Relating To The Flaming Lips|accessdate=2013-02-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070329221215/http://www.wbr.com/flaminglips/cmp/marnov99.htm|archivedate=2007-03-29|df=}}</ref> Another headphone concert was performed in the [[Chapter Arts Centre]], [[Cardiff]] in April 2000 by [[Rocketgoldstar]].<ref name="BBC Music Live events unfold" />
Later headphone concerts used specially designed wireless 3-channel headphones, better in-house custom made transmitters and no speakers or any live PA in the venue. Major events hosting headphone concerts included the 2005 [[Glastonbury Festival]], [[2010 Shift Festival]] in Switzerland,<ref>{{cite web|last=Spirgi|first=Dominique|title=2010 Shift Festival english program|url=http://www.shiftfestival.ch/en/shift-2010/program/headphone-concerts/|work=2010 Shift Festival website|publisher=Shift Electronic Arts Festival Postfach CH-4023 Basel Switzerland|accessdate=2009-01-10}}</ref> the 2011-12 [[Van's Warp Tours]] across North America, [[Sensoria Music & Film Festival|Sensoria 2012]] in [[Sheffield, UK]], the 2012 [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]] in Tennessee and the [[Hoxeyville Music Fest]] in Michigan.<ref name="knoxnews.com">{{cite web|last=Brimer|first=Adam|title=Bonnaroo Silent Disco Day 1|url=http://www.knoxnews.com/photos/galleries/2012/jun/07/day-1-thursday-at-bonnaroo-2012/46908/|work=knox news|publisher=Knoxnews.com|accessdate=Dec 10, 2012}}</ref> In 2012, [[Kid Koala]] performed a "Space Cadet Headphone Concert tour" around the world.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/2012/04/kid_koala_space_cadet_headphone_experience_april_4_review.php | title = Live: Kid Koala's Space Cadet Headphone Experience Crashes In Brooklyn - New York - Music - Sound of the City | accessdate = 2013-02-21 | last = Mlynar | first = Phillip | date = 2012-04-05 | publisher = [[Village Voice]]}}</ref>
A variant of the headphone concert involves live bands competing for the audience, who are able to choose which band's frequency to receive. In August 2008, the first silent [[Battle of the Bands]] was held at [[Barfly (club)|The Barfly]] music venue in [[Cardiff]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejoycollective.co.uk/blog/uncategorized/preview-silent-gig-featuring-kutosismuscle-club-and-others-barfly-wed-13th-august|title= Silent Gig featuring Kutosis/Muscle Club and others @ Barfly : Wed 13th August |publisher=Joy Collective|accessdate=2008-08-08|last=|first= | date=}}</ref> The event featured bands going directly head-to-head, with a stage at each end of the venue, allowing gig-goers to choose which group they wished to listen to.
==Silent theatre== Theatre and performance companies are now beginning to exploit silent disco technology as well. In 2009, with the help of SilentArena Ltd, Feral Productions began using an experimental approach – a mixture of narrative-led performance, [[sound art]] and guided exhibit. Their first performance, ''The Gingerbread House'', took the audience from The [[Courtyard, Hereford]] on a journey through a [[multi-storey car park]] in the centre of Hereford. In 2010, their second show, ''Locked (Rapunzel’s Lament)'', took place in a children’s playground, also in Hereford. Silent theatre techniques are now being used by companies in Liverpool, Birmingham and Glasgow.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.herefordtimes.com/leisure/reviews/4715331.Thinking_out_of_the_dramatic_box/ |title=The Gingerbread House breaks dramatic boundaries in Hereford |accessdate= |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |format= |work= |publisher= |pages= |quote= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.herefordtimes.com/leisure/theatre/8383794.New_theatre_group___s_hoping_for_another_fairytale_ending_at_The_Courtyard_in_Hereford/ |title=Feral Productions' hoping for another fairytale ending at The Courtyard in Hereford |accessdate= |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |format= |work= |publisher= |pages= |quote= }}</ref>
In 2015 [[Lincoln Center]] staged a production of the [[Rocky Horror Picture Show]] utilizing Quiet Events Headphones,<ref>{{cite web|title=Quiet Theater|url=https://quietevents.com/quiet-theater/|website=Quiet Events|publisher=Quiet Events|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref> where an audience wearing headphones could switch between the audio for the live performance and the soundtrack of the film version being projected behind it.<ref>{{Cite news|title = ‘Rocky Horror’ at Lincoln Center, With Headphones|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/10/movies/rocky-horror-in-central-park-with-headphones.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-08-09|access-date = 2015-09-25|issn = 0362-4331|first = Dave|last = Itzkoff}}</ref>
== Silent street shows == Street performers have used the concept as a solution to overcome bans on amplification and loudspeakers on the street. In 2016, Irish band [[Until April]] began using this for their shows on the street while touring in Germany and Switzerland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.advertiser.ie/galway/article/86139/galway-duo-find-novel-way-to-overcome-amplifier-bans-on-continental-europe|title=Galway duo find novel way to overcome amplifier bans on continental Europe|access-date=2016-07-21}}</ref>

[[File:Guadalajara, Jalisco, México 23.0.jpg|thumb|300px|Teatro degollado.]]
'''Teatro Degollado''' ({{IPA-es|teˈatɾo ðeɣoˈʝaðo|lang}}, ''[[Santos Degollado|Degollado]] Theater'') is a [[neoclassicism|neoclassical]]<ref name=gdltours>[http://www.gdltours.com/degollado_theater_guadalajara.html " Guadalajara Historic District Teatro Degollado "], "gDLtours".</ref> Mexican theater known for its diverse performances and artistic design. It is located in the central plaza of [[Guadalajara]], [[Jalisco]], Mexico on Belen Street between Hidalgo Avenue and Morelos Avenue. Many performances (from cultural Mexican dances to international operas) take place in this building.<ref name=discover>[http://discovermexicoadventures.web.officelive.com/TeatroDegollado.aspx “Teatro Degollado”] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814165111/http://discovermexicoadventures.web.officelive.com/TeatroDegollado.aspx |date=2011-08-14 }}, "Discover Mexico Adventures".</ref> Meant to be a monument of Guadalajara's culture, the theater was inaugurated in September 1866; breathing life to the city through its innovative artistic beauty.
== Original plans == Degollado Theater was constructed during Mexico's 1800's theatrical movement. There was a high demand for a great theater in Guadalajara, Jalisco that displayed the cultural arts of the city.<ref name=discover/> In response to the demand, on October 1, 1855, Antonio Perez Verdia proposed the construction of Alarcon Theater (after the classic dramatist [[Juan Ruiz de Alarcon]])<ref name=costa>[http://www.costalegre.org/Cultural-Centers/teatro-degollado.html "Teatro Degollado"], "Costa Alegre & Mexico Practical Travel Guide", Tuesday July 06, 2008.</ref> to the current governor of the time, [[Santos Degollado]]. On December 12 of that same year, Degollado signed the official decree to build the structure, and in March, 1856, Degollado set the first cornerstone of the building. In April 1856, Jacobo Galvez was appointed to lead the initial construction of the theater.<ref name=gdltours/><ref name=centenario>Pizano y Saucedo, Carlos. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/25134633 "Centenario del “Teatro Degollado” De Guadalajara"], "[[El Colegio de México]]", Guadalajara.</ref>
Due to a three-year war in Mexico, and a change of government during the dispute, the completion of the project was slow. On November 12, 1861, Governor Pedro Amazon changed the proposed name of the project from the "Alarcon Theater" to the "Degollado Theater", after ex-governor and general at the time of his death, Santos Degollado (killed in a battle on June 16, 1861).<ref name=gdltours/><ref name=discover/><ref name=costa/> This change of name was not acknowledged at the time of inauguration, but was adopted on December 18, 1866, when Mexican liberal troops regained control of the plaza where the theater is located.<ref name=centenario/>
== First inauguration == The theater's first inauguration was on September 13, 1866, with the opera "[[Lucia di Lammermoor]]", performed by [[Angela Peralta]], opera soprano noted as the "Mexican Nightingale".<ref name=gdltours/><ref name=costa/> At this point in time the theater had not been completed. Subsequently, there were many renovations and four more inaugurations.<ref name=centenario/>
== Inauguration dates == These are the dates of all the inaugurations following renovations of the structure:
* September 13, 1866 * October 30, 1880 * September 15, 1910 * June 28, 1941 * September 8, 1964 <ref name=centenario/>
== Artistic design == Degollado Theater is famous for its beautiful paintings along its golden walls on the interior of the building and its symbolic mosaic on the exterior.
===Interior ===
Most of the theater's renovations were made to improve the interior design by adding paintings and giving it its current red and golden color. Before the theater's first inauguration, Gerardo Suarez and Carlos Villasenor decorated the theater with a mural representing [[Dante Alighieri]]'s fourth song in the [[Divine Comedy]].<ref name=discover/> On 1877, Fermin Riestra was ordered to continue with the construction of the building; a three-year process on which a gilded eagle holding a Mexican flag on its talons and a chain on its beak was placed on the center of the inner arch of the building. Within the three year construction, Felipe Castro painted the murals ''Time and Hours'' and ''The Fame'' on the proscenium arch. Between 1880 and 1890, the stucco on the concert hall was completed and a golden color was added to the interior walls. By 1893, tiles were removed from the stage, due to the lack of support they provided for the structure, and were replaced by a metal arch on 1905. Between 1909 and 1910 artist [[Roberto Montenegro]] focused on the reconstruction and decoration of the interior of the building which included the addition of a crystal lamp on the theater's vault. Fifty years later, architect Ignacio Diaz Morales was in charge of a complete restoration of the building where sculptures by Benito Castaneda replaced Venetian mosaics. On May 2001, a chamber hall that can hold 200 people was added to the inside of the building.<ref name=gdltours/><ref name=centenario/>
===Exterior===
With fewer renovations than the interior, the exterior of the building still retains its artistic beauty. Between 1953 and 1959 Montenegro painted the mosaic of Apollo and the nine muses on the [[pediment]] of the theater. The portico supporting the pediment consists of 16 [[corinthian order|Corinthian]] columns.<ref name=gdltours/><ref name=costa/> When Ignacio Diaz was in charge of the renovation of the theater, he ordered the engraving of the phrase "May we never hear a hint of discord" along Montenegro's mosaic on the main entrance.<ref name=discover/>
==Building's dimensions== Several measurements of the Theater: *Building measures 97 m long, 36.4 m wide, and 22.5 m high. *Stage measures 54 m by 18 m.<ref name=gdltours/> *Oval hall measures 10 m × 6.5 m wide. *Building capacity of 1,015 spectators.<ref name=gdltours/> <ref name=discover/>
